PETITION.TITLE: Australian Service Medal

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes

That certain Trade Unions are currently forcing employers and employees to join union-controlled Superannuation schemes through industrial blackmail, thereby extending the Unions' economic power and at the same time infringing individual rights.

(i) Guarantee that Occupational Superannuation is a matter of individual choice

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
In this session of Parliament the proposed Bill of Rights will come before the Senate to be debated.
We, the undersigned, would like to voice our protest at the proposed Bill.

1. Because of the haste and secrecy with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives despite the fact that it will adversely affect areas of immense importance to liberty and freedom and is contrary to the spirit of the Australian Constitution.

2. The Bill is based upon the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which has been rejected both by the United States of America and Great Britain but accepted by the Warsaw Pact countries. We therefore believe there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many whom do not practice the principles that they have covenanted to uphold.

3. Because our Australian Constitution states that `whereas we the people' give you the government, these rights, the Constitution limits the right and power of government. The proposed Bill of Rights reverses this totally and states that `we the government, give you the people these rights'. This totally reverses the nature of government in this country.
4. Our rights and the principles of freedom are now protected by current legislation, Common law and the present Constitution.
5. Because it transfers the power of interpretation of legislation from the Parliament of Australia (the democratically elected institution) to the Courts (unelected body of people).

6. Because the Bill of Rights will be administrated by the Human Rights Commission which is an unelected body of people with powers which are outside and not subject to the normal processes of law-no appeal, closed hearings, no legal presentation.

7. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights and just as inevitably the centralised control, by government, on human behaviour.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights in any shape or form being introduced in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation

Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject the Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I table the report on the philosophy, aims and policy guidelines for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education developed by the National Aboriginal Education Committee. I seek leave to make a statement relating thereto.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The NAEC is the Government's principal adviser in the field of Aboriginal education. I value that advice very highly. In this report as in all its work, the NAEC has taken pains to ensure that its approach reflects Aboriginal community views, that its conclusions have been reached only after extensive consultation, and that its recommendations are directly related to the resolution of some of the practical, day-to-day problems facing Aboriginals. All honourable senators will appreciate the difficulties entailed in formulating a coherent and comprehensive set of aims and guidelines for all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. We need to start, as the NAEC has started, by recognising the importance of diversity, of flexibility, of incremental progress and of continuing consultations with all the communities involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The NAEC report presents, in a particularly cogent and sometimes trenchant way, the views of my Aboriginal advisers about future directions for Aboriginal education. Its conclusions are challenging. The NAEC has focused especially on: The full recognition and development in education of Aboriginal cultural heritage; the desirability of ensuring that education is undertaken in harmony with cultural values and choice of lifestyle, for Aboriginals living in urban areas as well as for those in traditional communities or homeland centres; the importance of including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies in the curriculum in early childhood, primary, secondary and tertiary education; as a corollary, the importance of establishing programs which promote cross-cultural understanding. I accept those points of emphasis. I accordingly accept that Aboriginal people should be given the responsibility to participate in planning policies to implement the programs envisaged and to take on a major role in teaching services throughout the Commonwealth.

I spent last week travelling through the Northern Territory examining Aboriginal education and training programs which we help to finance and co-ordinate. Honourable senators will be aware of the Government's substantial financial commitments in this field and of the range of innovative programs we-in co-operation with the States and the Northern Territory-have helped develop. Many urgent and basic questions still need to be resolved. They concern the priority to be given to bilingual education, the need to expand the range of vocational training provided, the importance of increasing the numbers of Aboriginal teachers in Aboriginal communities, and-perhaps most important of all-the need to develop courses so that they lead on to productive jobs, either in the general labour market or in Aboriginal communities. We need time and money to solve those problems, but we also need enthusiasm, energy, dedication and commitment. Those qualities are evident in every section of the document I have just tabled, and in all the work of the NAEC.

Our policies in the field of Aboriginal education are developed in full co-operation with the States and the Northern Territory. We would also welcome co-operation from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The stakes are too high for any partisan squabbling or divisions. We all need to work together to make progress in the important areas the NAEC has outlined, since achievement of those aims will benefit and develop all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper and statement.

It is good to have this statement by the National Aboriginal Education Committee before the Senate and to have the accompanying ministerial statement of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). Like some other senators here, I have worked with Mr Paul Hughes, Mr Errol West and other members of the NAEC and have appreciated the work they are doing and the goals they are seeking to achieve. I would like to emphasise something the Minister did not emphasise, but which I know she would share, and that is the extent of Aboriginal disadvantage in almost any area one cares to measure. Whether it is health, education, employment or other adverse things such as rates of imprisonment or sickness, Aboriginal Australians are at the bottom of every statistical table. They bear an enormous burden of disadvantage and this extends across to education.

I remember well when I first came to this place I went to Walgett with a Senate committee under the chairmanship of then Senator Keeffe. We met with the principal of the primary school there, Mr Laurie Craddock, who told us that when he came to the school the rate of illiteracy and the inability to read or write at the end of grade 6 had been a figure which was exactly equal to the rate of Aboriginal enrolment in that primary school. He had been able in his time there to introduce programs which had altered completely that rate of illiteracy and innumeracy. He had people reading, writing and participating in education. The same Laurie Craddock has gone on to promotion. I think he is now a very senior officer in the Education Department in New South Wales, and it is no wonder with that kind of commitment and achievement.

One of the things that emerged, with which the Minister would agree, is that some of the reasons people were not achieving well was that perhaps the educational programs were not appropriate, but in addition to that there were factors of health-people could not hear what the teachers were saying and they were inadequately nourished-and their home circumstances were not adequate to allow them to cope well in the school environment. So we had a tragedy in education as it affected Aboriginal Australians. They saw it as giving them nothing. The question that has always concerned me is the extent to which a school system which represents the dominant culture in society can be expected and required to meet the needs of any minority group or culture. We certainly have that expectation, but we have plenty of evidence that the school system fails far too often to meet the needs of minority groups in the community.

Of course, it is not all negative. We have some emerging examples of continuing Aboriginal educational successes. I notice in this report, which I have had a chance to scan but not to read, a photograph of Eric Wilmot. This remarkable Australian, who happens to be an Aboriginal, was a stockman until his mid-20s when he went back and took some further education. He then qualified at tertiary level. He was the Director of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. Three or four years ago he was the Australian inventor of the year because he invented a new gear-box which is now coming into production. He is now the professor of education at James Cook University. No great fuss; he just happens to be an Aboriginal. There is a whole group of Aboriginal Australians emerging now who have succeeded in a big way through our education system.

I am not suggesting that it is all negative, but if one looks at statistics it has been far too negative. The NAEC is quite correct to draw attention to the need to do something, because the problem is there. When we look at what might be done, one of the things for which I hope the NAEC would push very hard is the inclusion of strands about Aboriginal Australians in the general education curriculum for all Australians. While we are worrying about the educational needs of Aboriginal Australians, all of us need to be made aware of the Aboriginal history of this country and of the way in which we interact with Aboriginal Australians. Not enough is being done in the general educational stream to pick up those strands.

It is not necessarily enough to propose a separate education system. One approach might be for the Aboriginal people to say: `The only way to solve this is to give us our own educational system to allow us to march to our own drum.' In some circumstances that might help.

We have done a number of things which apply specifically to Aboriginals. I am reminded of the Aboriginal secondary grants scheme, under which certain resources are made available for Aboriginal secondary students. When I was Minister what emerged very rapidly was that there was nothing wrong at all with that scheme, but that there were many poor white Australians who could equally have taken advantage from it. Many of the things which are being proposed by the NAEC in fact could be of benefit to a wider group of clients. I think the focus of education in Australia really has to be to equip, enrich and empower children to control their own lives when they become adults. If those are the aims of education, clearly education has failed Aboriginal Australians over some generations. Too many of the people I have met have certainly not felt they have been enriched, empowered or equipped. On that basis education has been a failure.

The Minister has asked us for multipartisan support for the kind of approach she is seeking. Many of the things which are being proposed and which she has mentioned we certainly do support. For example, some of the references to bilingual and bicultural education we think can do nothing but good and we would like to see something done. But the key to multipartisan support will not just be fine sentiments or fine words; it will be action by the Government, action which we can see to put into place some of the proposals which the National Aboriginal Conference has been putting up. If the Government, in fact, intends to reject the NAEC suggestions on good grounds, it should come here and say so, but it should indicate what it intends to do to pursue the goals of equipping, enriching and empowering Aboriginal Australians, for in the end nothing less will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has introduced a report by the National Aboriginal Education Committee entitled `Philosophy, aims and policy guidelines for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education'. As Senator Peter Baume has suggested, the statement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) is full of fine words. I do not feel at all charitable towards the Government in terms of Aboriginal education or anything to do with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders at the moment, and certainly not this week with its historical type of denigration and backing off from the policies that it has already announced. Having attended a very large meeting last night of over 400 Aboriginals I can assure the Senate that they feel exactly the same.

SPEECH.PARA: We again have a set of fine words which presumably will result in exactly the same type of action as the last lot of fine words we had in these areas. In 1984 the NAEC issued a report entitled `TAFE for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders'. What has happened? Almost nothing. It then issued a further statement entitled `Aborigines and Tertiary Education: A Framework for the 1985-87 Triennium'. What has happened there? Almost nothing. The Minister's statement contains fine words, but I doubt whether we will see any type of implementation of those proposals, as we have not seen anything from previous reports of this Committee.

The Committee has put forward a very cogent and a very forceful position that has to be taken account of. This week, Aboriginal groups concerned about the media, which is an incredibly important part of education in Australia, are awaiting some response from the Minister as to whether the types of support statements that have been made, will be followed by cash commitments. Next Monday, these people will appear before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to argue their case for getting the footprint satellite over north Australia. The Minister is too busy to meet with them this week. They have been advised to tell the Tribunal to put off its hearings for a month. They have been given the general runaround. Yet the central zone Aussat satellite footprint will obviously be of vital importance to Aboriginal people in terms of their culture and intrusion into their culture. It has as much to do with education, and possibly more, than do schools. Yet the Government makes no commitment. It just tells them to go away and not to bother. It tells them to tell the Tribunal to put off its discussions.

On the one hand we get these fine words, but what do we get on the other? The commitment of this situation is important. An agreement to consider these types of recommendations is important. I, like Senator Peter Baume, wait for the Government's response in terms of what it will do, not what it says it will do. It is fairly obvious to me that if Aboriginal and Islander people are given an opportunity to involve themselves in media production, they will be able to provide to their people enormous educational benefits. Yet the Torres Strait Islander people were not even informed of the hearing into the granting of a commercial licence in north Queensland. They were not even told that there was an inquiry into the granting of a commercial licence for a television station which will beam into their area. Anyone who has visited those islands would have an understanding that the intrusion of commercial television will probably be more important than the establishment of a school in changing that community's culture and setup. Quite frankly, at least from my perspective and certainly from the perspective of those Aboriginals who attended the meeting last night, they can no longer trust this Government. They wait for action. They wait for the Government's announcements about what it will do, rather than pronouncements about its good intentions.

I will reserve my judgment with regard to this report until we hear from the Government and its commitments-and its financial commitments-to the goals that are set out in this report. I think the Government is very lucky to have a committee of this calibre. It has been the case on so many occasions in the past that the Aboriginal committees that have been formed to advise the Government have almost invariably produced conscientious, far-sighted reports. Of course, the major Aboriginal consultative body has been destroyed. I ask the Minister in this House for a commitment on when it would be replaced. I was told it would be replaced in June last year. I now understand that no funds will be available until June next year-two years later than the commitment that was given in this place by the Minister for Education. The Aboriginal people put their position very strongly to me last night, and I think we are in a situation where we must remain totally sceptical about the Government's good intentions in this regard. We must call for action in these areas before we can go any further.

The report refers to a number of significant advances that Aboriginal people have made in various areas. I think we are all now very much aware of that. We have all met Aboriginals who have completed a variety of tertiary education courses. For the first time we have an Aboriginal doctor. We also have increasing numbers of Aboriginal lawyers and Aboriginal teachers. In many cases those people are dedicating themselves, in a very self-sacrificing way, to the advancement of their people. I think what they are doing puts many of us in the white community to shame. They are putting aside what could be lucrative careers and devoting themselves to their own people. They are setting an example to so many others. One finds, in talking to teachers of Aboriginal students, that for the first time there is a turnaround; that many Aboriginal students now want to go on because they can see the successes that have been achieved by other Aboriginal people.

Let us not put it down to the fact that governments have caused this. By and large almost every one of those people have done it on their own. They have worked through the normal system. At the moment very little has come of arrangements such as the enclave at Monash University to assist people. We hope that those types of developments will proliferate in the future because there is a need for accelerated courses in these areas. We need to be able to say to the triple certificated Aboriginal nurses who wish to become doctors that we will establish special courses for them. These nurses have seen it all. They operate in communities where they are the only medical health provider. They deal with every conceivable problem that is presented to them. Many of the nurses who have had experience in the field and have worked in the area of medicine for long periods now wish to become doctors. As yet the only courses which have been offered to them are courses in other countries. One Aboriginal nurse said to me that she wishes to undertake her training in Australia. She does not wish to study at a university in the United States of America that has offered her a free place and a scholarship. She wants to do it in this country because she is an Australian. I hope that we will be able to discuss these matters more extensively at some other stage.

Education is, of course, of vital concern to Aboriginal communities. One cannot visit and talk for any length of time with members of any Aboriginal group without being made very aware of their commitment and drive to make sure that a number of their people achieve so that they can take their place and argue their own role in the white society. I remember quite vividly talking to an Aboriginal school principal in Arnhem Land. When I asked him about the attendance record of kids since he became the principal, he said: `We now have all the Aboriginal children attending'. I said: `How do you achieve it?' He said: `I go around and kick their backsides if they do not come'. That was an interesting comment because for the first time in that community the Aboriginal children, who attend a school which has white teachers on the staff, have to do what they are told by an Aboriginal principal. The mere fact of putting an Aboriginal principal in charge of the school has created a totally different model for those children, a model which has shown that Aboriginal people do not always have to tug the forelock, that they do not always have to be in subservient positions, that they are as capable as any other Australian of taking positions of command, authority and eminence in our society. It is a pity, in view of the racist campaigns that have been conducted over the past few years in Australia, that some people did not spend some time, some energy and some grey matter on talking and thinking with those Aboriginal people about the ways in which they wish to advance themselves. I have nothing against the statement that the Minister has made. I think the report is excellent, pointing the way forward for government action. My only concern is the possibility of no government action to follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, may I first say how pleased I am to see you back in the chair after a long absence. It is a return that is welcomed by all of us, but on behalf of the Opposition I certainly welcome you.
—Thank you.

—Senator Macklin, in his response on behalf of the Australian Democrats to the statement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), gave the Senate a timely reminder of some of the Government's manifest failures in Aboriginal affairs. The Minister in this statement has called for bipartisanship, and that is a call to which I wish to respond. I do not wish to labour the point but, since this is the first parliamentary opportunity I have had to speak on this subject since the Government announced its attitude on the national land rights question, I think I should say in this place, as I have said outside, that I believe that the proper course would be for the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), to resign, and indeed for Senator Ryan to resign, given the clear promises that they made to the Aboriginal people of Australia over a long period in opposition and in Government, promises which they have now clearly dishonoured. The fact that they dishonoured them is not a point of issue in that the decision to move back to a federalist approach is welcomed by the Opposition, but I think it represents a very poor manifestation of any political principles, and in my view the honourable course for both Ministers would be resignation.

SPEECH.PARA: To return, however, to the matter before the Senate, which is the report of the National Aboriginal Education Committee, I think it important to focus on the real prospects for common cause in this area. Aboriginal affairs has become a very divisive area in Australian politics, but I think no Australian would wish to deny to Aboriginal Australians an education which would help to equip them for life in Australia in the 1980s. I think that all Australians would wish to see achieved the broad objectives laid down by the National Aboriginal Education Committee. If I could single out one objective that I think is of critical importance, it is the objective that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education lead to personal development and the acquisition of skills and learning needed for Australia today. That point is acknowledged in the Minister's statement where she says that perhaps the most important thing of all is to develop courses so that they lead to productive jobs either in the general labour market or in Aboriginal communities. Indeed, it goes beyond the question of jobs; it goes into education for the general life skills required for the sort of personal independence that Senator Peter Baume referred to.

None of us wishes to delay the return to the debate on the Bill of Rights, but it is an indication of the interest which honourable senators have in this topic that a number of other Opposition senators wish to speak after me. I acknowledge the interest of Senator Sir John Carrick with whom I spent some time in the Northern Territory when he had Senator Ryan's job as Minister for Education. We took that trip specifically to visit Aboriginal communities and to discuss the sorts of issues dealt with in this report. I acknowledge his contribution in this area.

More recently I went to the Central Reserve with Mr Ross Lightfoot who is now the member for Murchison-Eyre following the recent State election in Western Australia. It was a notable feature of that visit, which took him not only to the Central Reserve but also to Wiluna and Mount Margaret, that there has been a very considerable development of educational facilities in that area. I must say that I was impressed by the expansion and refinement of facilities since my last visit in the 1980s. I think that some of the issues which are brought out in the National Aboriginal Education Committees report become very apparent when one visits those communities and sees the work which is being done.

Whilst acknowledging the very great personal contribution which has been made by individual teachers, the contribution of the Western Australian Education Department in the provision of what seemed to me to be some very high standard facilities, the contribution which was made by the Aboriginal curriculum development people in Western Australia and the work of people such as May O'Brien, who will be well known to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I can say only that many questions are left in one's mind about the ability of the current educational system to equip young Aboriginal people for independent lives in the community, whether it be within the central reserves, those outback towns or in the cities if the people choose to move there. I do not think any of us should underestimate the very great difficulties facing those people in making the transition from their present situation to one of greater personal independence.

My main purpose in speaking in this debate was to say that I think this matter will require the sort of bipartisan co-operation which the Minister has sought and which I am sure will be forthcoming from the Opposition on this important issue. It will also require the taking of a long view. There is no prospect that by dint of some inspired government intervention over a short period there will be a complete turnaround and a complete solution. It requires a multi-generational approach. We have to be prepared to put in a consistent effort over a very long time. I ask the Government when making its response to the National Aboriginal Education Committee report to take that very long view and to commit itself to a consistent and principled approach to the education of Aboriginal and Islander people. That means giving good support to those non-Aboriginal Australians who go to live in areas which are often very difficult to provide the essential input at the professional level.

I am very pleased that Mr Ross Lightfoot has taken such a positive interest in this issue and in other aspects relating to the Aboriginal population in his electorate. I believe that he also would wish to work in a bipartisan manner with the present Labor Government in Western Australia and with the new Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Ernie Bridge, who faces very great challenges as an Aboriginal person holding that office in Western Australia. I for my part look forward to working with Mr Lightfoot and, indeed, with everbody who is concerned with advancing Aboriginal education not only in Western Australia but also around the rest of Australia.

I commend the report for the Government's earnest consideration. I welcome the Minister's suggestion that we should adopt an approach which involves co-operation from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. I express the general hope that, now that the Government has taken its more difficult decisions in the field of land rights, we can move to a broader bipartisan approach to Aboriginal affairs in other areas to the very great advantage of Aboriginal people and, I believe, to the very great advantage of the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also welcome the report of the National Aboriginal Education Committee entitled `Philosophy, aims and policy guidelines for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education'. In the time that is briefly available, I wish to add to the comments of my colleagues Senator Peter Baume and Senator Chaney and those of Senator Sir John Carrick, who will speak after me, in welcoming this report and in commending the work of the National Aboriginal Education Committee. Whilst I also welcome the statement made in the chamber this morning by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), I reiterate our common theme that we will be looking for credibility in those statements through the actions of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last fortnight's session when the Minister brought down a ministerial statement on national language policy which contained the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts reports and recommendations in that field, I had similar things to say. I was concerned that the Minister's warm and happy statement of commitment and of promise needed to be followed up with distinct action. In respect to this particular report, my colleagues and I believe-and I am sure that the Minister will share our view-that Paul Hughes and his Committee colleagues are doing an excellent job in working with Aboriginal communities throughout Australia and in giving advice to us all on ways of overcoming the disadvantage of which Senator Peter Baume spoke clearly in his remarks.

I wish to focus on the remarks in the report that relate to the Torres Strait Islanders as one particular group of Aborigines which is in need of enhanced education programs. The report refers very positively to bilingual, bicultural education and a number of us in the Senate have been dismayed that, whilst there have been real advanced, for example in the north of South Australia in remote Aboriginal communities and the Northern Territory particularly throughout the 1970s, there are significant areas, not least the Kimberleys, remote areas of New South Wales and more particularly north Queensland where there is more evidence of deficiency. In north Queensland inadequate resources have been given to teacher education and there has been inadequate planning and provision for bilingual education. The report that has been presented to the Senate rightly emphasises that the language of many Australians is an Aboriginal language such as Kala Laga Ya in the Torres Strait area, which is the majority language of most of the outer islands, and Merriam Mer, the distinctly different family of languages related to Papua, which is spoken on Murray Island. There are not only those historic indigenous languages, but also Aboriginal English and Torres Strait Kriol. There is a recognition in this report that the means to the best foundation for education of children in that area, as we have seen in South Australia and the Northern Territory, is a bilingual approach in the primary years. There is reference in the report to this trend continuing to Year 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I join with Senator Chaney in welcoming you to the chair and in wishing you many years amongst us in the full health that you are now enjoying. I also welcome the report of the National Aboriginal Education Committee. That committee is a body of very great significance to Australia. I have been associated with it in the past and I know of its expertise and the value of its advice. I rise because essential to the report is the necessity expressed by my colleagues to get well established bipartisanship on this issue in the longer term. If indeed, in the course of my remarks, I appear to be somewhat critical of or abrasive towards the Government it is only to expose the difficulties and to move towards a centre stage. I acknowledge the happy smile of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and I hope he will join me on the journey.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say this, and it may be taken as abrasive, that when I took over as Federal Minister for Education in late 1975, and I had an exciting journey of some four years in that portfolio, I found that by far the greatest problem that confronted me in education was the most difficult and complex problem of the Australian Aborigine. When I started I thought that I knew some of the solutions. After four years I concluded that I knew the questions to be asked, but not the solutions. It is very important indeed to know the questions, because if one knows the questions to ask, one might get the answers. I think that we have been asking the wrong questions. I must say again, and this can also be taken as abrasive, that I believe that both the Whitlam and the Hawke governments have suffered from the defect that they either have not truly understood the essential problems of the Aborigine or have not sought to and have rather sought to design the public relations label rather than the product. If one wants to damage an issue one looks to the public relations instead of the product. I believe fundamentally, and I say this from my heart, that the real problem is that there has been a growing alienation between the Aboriginal community and the rest of the Australian community because of the failure to tell the caucasian community, the white Australian community, the nature of the problem and how we can come together in its solution.

A lot of very clever phrases have been used in this respect, phrases such as: `You, the Aboriginal people, can have a choice-you can go back to your own cultures and live in them, you can come into ours or you can commute'. That all sounds grand but the fact is that from the moment the first white man came to Australia that position was totally compromised. It was compromised not only by force or dispossession-they themselves were ugly things-but also by more fundamental things. The white man brought things that could not be described as a range of virtues, but more a range of defects for the Aborigine. The Aborigine found himself confronted with a whole range of white man's diseases, particularly upper respiratory tract infections and social diseases that he had not had before and could not cope with. If one visits an Aboriginal school the first problem one notices is otitis media, the disease of the middle ear, which Senator Peter Baume, as the previous Minister, would have known very well. That is a disease that so delimits the ability to hear that, until the penicillin needle can be brought to the student, a suitable environment cannot be created. That in itself is fundamental. The Aborigines also suffer conjunctival diseases of the eye and trachomas. The white man also brought his foods and created a whole host of changes. There was a change from a high animal protein diet to a diet which included dampers, sugars, teas and other substances which have created many problems. Middle age diabetes is a plague among Aborigines. Therefore it is no use saying that the Aborigine can go back to his own culture. He must go back with a penicillin needle, the sulphur drugs and the support systems that are needed.

We took a very proud people, people who were proud to be hunters and nomads, and told them they should put on clothes. We forced upon them our value judgments. Of course, in an environment where there is no dry cleaning and there are no washing machines, we have helped them along to an environment of lice, vermin and destruction. When we see Aborigines sitting in the creek bed, clothed and looking derelict, we tend to denigrate them and criticise them; but they are our creation, in the same way as 350 years ago the Americans brought the negroes from Africa and set about changing and compromising the whole future of those people. We cannot say: `Get back to your own culture'. We have done more than that. We found a people who were nomads, with a culture entirely different from ours, who never built a permanent structure or home, who never undertook animal husbandry or agriculture but who were very competent in living in a vast and difficult society. They could live in a forbidding land and survive essentially because of the packing together of the extended family. We cannot understand that extended family as a belonging of 50 to 100 people packed together.

Thinking to be helpful, we have applied to them our social security and health schemes. We have said to them: `You can go back to your cultures; you can go from the towns to the settlements, to the outstations, to the homelands, but you take your social security benefits with you'. That situation in itself is now past change, but in doing that we have said to those people that they have no need for significance in their community, no need to strive, no need to hunt, no need to forage, because we will support them totally with social security. We ourselves have created the dilemma. I am not saying for one minute that I would not take the penicillin needles, that I would not take the support systems. That is not part of what I am saying. I am saying that, the Europeans having compromised the situation, we must try to understand the Aborigines and how they find themselves today.

When we look at the human conflict in suburbs such as Redfern we tend to take a brutal view. We tend to fail to understand a people who have lived in their skin groups and clans and who fervently want to be together. By advocating that the support systems go out, the whole of the culture based on hunting and foraging and the dream worlds as the protector of the family group has gone. We find them sitting in dirty clothes in creek beds, but it is we who through our systems have brought this about. It is we who basically have stripped from them their human dignity.

I do not want fine phrases. I accept that on both sides of this place there is understanding. I look to Senator Robertson, for example, and acknowledge his sympathetic understanding of these people. I look to many other honourable senators. What I do not want are fine phrases. I want a policy that allows us all to move together to rebuild the dignity of the individual human in the best way we can, wherever we find that human being-whether we find him tribalised, on the settlements, the outstations, the homelands, whether moving between those places, or in Redfern or Fitzroy. What we need to do is, first of all, to understand the plight they are in at this moment and then try to work with them.

We are dealing with the Bill of Rights in this House, and the most important freedom and liberty a man has-if I can express it so-is his responsibility to respect the right of the other fellow to be free and different. That is very hard because here is a culture which is so different from ours that it offends us. I once said to a very fine Aborigine at Yirrkala in the Gove Peninsula: `Look, I can get you the garbage contract, worth $200 a week. It would be good.' He said: `Why should I? If I do, I have to take the money back to the fifty people who are part of my group. I will have to share it.' There is a kind of collective sharing in the extended Aboriginal family that we do not understand. It was not that that person was, in the good old Australian phrase, a bludger or that the rest of them were bludgers but that that was the situation those people found themselves in. We need to work within that context and we need to do it throughout the whole of Australia.

I have risen to my feet primarily to say that the first step we should take is to disabuse the bulk of the Australian people of the ugliness of this problem. We should strip back the image of drunkenness, of violence, of dirt, of lack of employment, and understand why this has happened. We should realise that we can never again let them live wholly in the culture in which they once were. That culture has gone with the introduction of all man's diseases and all man's support systems. We should never brutalise but always try to keep the dignity of the people as we move along.

We can do that best of all in an education system because we have the whole variety of education through all its different phases in Australia. When I was Education Minister I tried to get affirmative action for Aborigines. I tried to say that of the 150,000 Aborigines in Australia there were probably only about 30,000 or 40,000 who were adults and who wanted work. If Federal, State and local governments had affirmative action and were to pick out Aborigines here and there and offer them work, not in some compartmentalised system but understanding that Aborigines are different and need encouragement and help, we could absorb that whole employment demand ourselves, without asking private enterprise to do so. Using a perhaps pejorative phrase, in the ordinary concept of things there are people in Australian employment designated as `slow workers'. What we ought to do by way of affirmative action is to make available in every niche a place for Aborigines, but only where those around them understand their nature, their culture and want to help them. Otherwise the difficulty will be immense.

I rose particularly to commend the National Aboriginal Education Committee and the various recommendations. The warts have been on the nose of all governments. The warts are on the nose of the Australian community. I do not defend law-breaking Aborigines, as I do not defend others who break the law. I do not defend that at all. I try to explain it. I do not try to whitewash the situation at all. My basic plea is for both Government and Opposition to enter into a compact to tell the Australian people what the problems are. If we tell the Australian people what the problems are and they become sympathetic, as they ought to be and must be if we are to have a solution, then the solution will be found within the community itself. Solutions come with human understanding. They come with affection and with a reaching hand. Above all, they come with the desire to protect and preserve the right of those people to be different. They are different. They are fundamentally different in every ethnic way. It is not for us to force them into a compromise to be like us. To force people to be like us is an abrogation of all human freedoms. We have to recognise that they are compromised and that they cannot go back, but that they have a culture which is as rich or richer than ours and religions and tribal rituals which are richer than ours and that we will try to protect them. We must look to the NAEC and other groups and stop trying to score political points against each other about who aids the Aborigines and who has done more for the Aborigines. The fact is that we have had a failure of understanding of the real problem. If we get to a true position of bipartisanship then the Aboriginal people in Australia can live with dignity and a great future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

On the 10th of December 1985, the Government announced its intention to continue the highly successful Community Employment Program (CEP) for a further three years beyond 30 June 1986. This Bill is to give effect to that intention. The CEP was introduced by the Hawke Government in August 1983 in response to the massive problem of long-term unemployment in the Australian labour market.

When this Government took office in March 1983 the Australian economy and labour market were in a parlous state. The economy was in deep recession, the worst for 50 years, and employment was continuing to plummet. By September 1983 the unemployment rate had reached a post war high of 10.4 per cent and the incidence of long-term unemployment had escalated alarmingly. The previous Government had failed utterly to fulfil its election promise to provide jobs for all those wanting work.

Despite the effects of international recession, the Hawke Government provided the environment and leadership to turn this tide. It came to office with a firm commitment to generate economic recovery through the pursuit of expansionary macroeconomic policies in the context of the historic prices and incomes accord with the trade union movement.
The Government's overall economic strategy has proved remarkably successful.
Economic growth has averaged around 5 per cent per annum, the highest rate of sustained growth since the late 1960s.

We undertook to create 500,000 jobs in the first three years in office, and this objective was achieved last November-5 months ahead of schedule. Over 548,100 new jobs have now been created since the Hawke Government came to office in March 1983, and our annual rate of employment growth of 3.8% during 1985 was the best performance by any Western industrialised country.
Unemployment has been reduced from over 10 per cent to less than 8 per cent.

Despite this impressive growth performance, the Government has always acknowledged the special difficulties faced by the long-term unemployed and other groups of disadvantaged jobseekers, such as Aboriginals, the disabled and migrants with English language difficulties.

These people have limited prospects of getting a job, even in times of general economic recovery. The longer a person is out of work the greater the loss of skills and confidence, and the more reluctant are employers to recruit such a person.
The incidence of long-term unemployment was a major social problem confronting the Hawke Government.
By November 1983, over 260,000 Australians or 41.8 per cent of all those out of work had been unemployed for 9 months or more.

This represented a tragic waste of human and economic resources which the Government was determined to address through special measures designed to improve the employment prospects of these disadvantaged jobseekers and enable them to share in the benefits of general economic recovery.

The Community Employment Program was our major response in this area. The Program provided worthwhile work experience on community-based and public sector projects for the long-term unemployed and other disadvantaged groups, with the objective of breaking the vicious circle of prolonged unemployment facing such people and assisting them back into the general labour market.
Legislation established the CEP as a three-year program when introduced in May 1983, and the Program was formally launched by the Prime Minister in August of that year.
The Hawke Government has allocated $1 billion to CEP in its first 3 budgets, which makes CEP the largest labour force program ever implemented by a Federal Government in Australia.
The results have been outstanding.
To date, Federal funds have been committed to provide for more than 16,000 projects sponsored by community organisations, local government and State and Federal Governments.
More than 87,000 short-term employment opportunities have been created for long-term unemployed and other disadvantaged jobseekers.
In terms of its targeting performance, CEP has been particularly impressive.

Long-term unemployed persons, ie. those with nine months or more prior unemployment represent over 62 per cent of all CEP placements to date, with 77 per cent of placements during 1985-86 being from this category. The average prior duration of unemployment amongst all CEP participants to date is 58 weeks and 70 weeks for those placed during this financial year. This is a remarkable achievement and shows that the Program is really reaching the core of long-term unemployed persons.

The CEP is also targeted towards migrants with English language difficulty, Aboriginals and disabled persons. Participation in the program by persons from these groups has increased progressively and is now well in excess of the representation of these groups amongst the ranks of those registered as unemployed with the CES. During this financial year 12 per cent of all placements have been Aboriginals, 14 per cent disabled persons and 10 per cent migrants with English language difficulties.

One of the most outstanding achievements of the CEP has been its success in meeting its objective of equal female representation in jobs created under the Program. The CEP was the first labour force program to take up the challenge of the Government's equal opportunity policy in this way.

To date the overall participation of women in the Program has been 38.6 per cent. This includes the Jobs on Local Roads component which initially did not have a target for women. If this component is excluded then the overall participation rate for women on projects approved to date is 42.7 per cent and on projects approved in 1985-86 it is 52.6 per cent. In 1985-86 the target of a 25 per cent placement rate for women on the local roads component is actually being exceeded by 5 per cent.

CEP has also proved extremely successful in improving the job prospects of those who have participated. A survey undertaken by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations in March 1985 showed that 41 per cent of ex-CEP participants were in employment 6 months after leaving CEP, with 59 per cent having been employed at some time during this 6 month period. A second survey in July 1985 indicated further improvements in these post-program results to 46 per cent and 61 per cent respectively. In addition, research by the Bureau of Labour Market Research shows that participants in this type of program experience a continuous improvement in psychological well being and are more able to cope with any subsequent period of unemployment than are non-program participants.

The decision to continue CEP is based on both evidence of the continuing need to assist the long-term unemployed and other disadvantaged groups in the labour market, and on its level of success to date.

Despite economic upturn there is no room for complacency about the employment prospects of the long-term unemployed. Although the number of people unemployed for 9 months or more has declined by 50,000 or 24 per cent to 210,300 over the two years to November 1985, there are still 92,400 who have been unemployed for two years or more. This latter group lost their jobs in the massive downturn in the labour market under the Fraser Government during 1982-83 and need the assistance of CEP.

The continuing need for assistance for the long-term unemployed is reinforced by short-term projections undertaken by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations which show that even under optimistic scenarios for economic and employment growth, the total number of long-term unemployed persons is not expected to fall significantly as a percentage of total unemployment over the next 2-3 years.

The success of the CEP has ensured that it will remain an important part of the Government's overall strategy for assisting unemployed persons. The CEP's public sector orientation, which creates work for those persons least able to benefit from employment opportunities created in a period of economic upturn, complements other Federal Government initiatives designed to assist the long-term unemployed, such as the wage subsidy schemes provided through the new Jobstart initiative.

Besides being successful in terms of its fundamental objectives the CEP can also be judged by its administrative performance. Cost effectiveness has been maintained in that 75 per cent of CEP funds are spent on labour, and administrative costs have been contained to 3 per cent of the CEP budget. A further positive efficiency indicator is the fact that the cost to the Commonwealth for a six month equivalent job has declined from $9,887 in 1983-84 to $9,817 in 1984-85.

In addition, the community at large has benefitted from the CEP. Although the major objective of the Program is to assist the long-term unemployed a secondary objective has been to provide services and facilities of community benefit. Consequently the Program has funded a variety of projects from road upgrading, parks and gardens, sport, recreation and tourism facilities, to environmental enhancement and arts and heritage projects.

The performance of CEP to date has been excellent. Although there have naturally been some operational problems, this is to be expected in a program of this size. The Government is currently in the process of consulting with those administrators and sponsors who have participated in the CEP in order to gain constructive input into the formulation of the new program. We believe that it is necessary to undertake this process of consultation before final decisions are taken both on the Program and Financial Guidelines which determine the structure and administrative arrangements for the new Program.

The Government is sure that this process will result in an even more effective program to assist the long-term unemployed whose disadvantage in the labour market still continues and is a major concern of this Government.

On the basis of CEP's success in meeting the needs of this group, its effective administration and its benefit to the community, the Government feels fully justified in continuing this important initiative. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

APPLE AND PEAR EXPORT UNDERWRITING AMENDMENT BILL 1986
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Act 1981. The Bill will come into effect on the day it receives Royal Assent.

The Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Act established an export underwriting scheme for apples and pears for the 1981-85 export seasons. Underwriting involves the guaranteeing of a minimum return by the Commonwealth Government in a year when prices fall below average export returns achieved in recent years. Its objective is to provide industry with an appropriate insurance against sharp export market downturns without masking longer term market trends.

Under the terms of the previous scheme underwriting payments were to be made on all exports of apples and pears, separately, in years when the average export return was less than the determined underwritten or ``floor'' price. The ``floor'' price was equal to 95% of the weighted average export return for the preceding four export seasons. An underwriting payment occurred in one year only-in 1981 when $4.8 million was paid in respect of exports of apples.

This Bill proposes that underwriting be extended for a further five years but under modified terms and conditions, both in respect of the previous scheme and also the recommendation of the Industries Assistance Commission in its 1985 Apples and Pears report. It is proposed that underwriting continue to operate separately for apples and pears but in addition it should now also apply, separately, to forward and at risk export sales. Forward sale exports are those which have been sold prior to shipment and `at risk' sales are those shipped before sale. In each instance, the ``floor'' price is to be at a level equal to 85% of the average return received for that type of sale in the best three of the preceding four seasons.

The Government considers that the proposed scheme is an improvement over the previous scheme and the IAC's recommendation. Major criticisms by industry of the previous scheme were that, given the relative differences in `at risk' and forward sale export returns for apples no meaningful underwriting insurance was being given to the apple industry and the method of calculating the floor price resulted in one bad price year unduly limiting the prospect of payouts in succeeding low price years.

Similarly, the IAC's recommendation involving underwriting `at risk' sales only, at a level of 80%, was seen by the industry as too restrictive. In addition there was particular concern that the IAC was proposing termination of underwriting for the industry after only three years.

It is considered that the terms of the Government's scheme contained in the Bill deal fully with these concerns. It is intended that the scheme be reviewed by the IAC prior to the end of the five years. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
AUSTRALIAN APPLE AND PEAR CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act 1973. The Bill will come into effect on the day it receives Royal Assent.

The Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act 1973 reconstituted the powers and composition of the previous Board and vested in the Corporation various export control powers and functions. One of these functions is to advise the Minister on those persons who may export apples and pears. Under the existing regulations apple and pear exporters must be licensed with licences issued by the Minister on the recommendation of the Corporation and subject to certain eligibility criteria, such as marketing experience and financial standing.

The Bill seeks to provide for the Corporation in future to issue export licences itself, rather than the Minister, and to be empowered to charge a licence administration fee. This will result in the Minister being removed from involvement in the day to day administration of the licensing system and is consistent with both the Government's policy relating to statutory marketing authorities in the primary industry area and existing legislative arrangements for meat exports.

As a separate but related issue the Corporation has agreed upon, in consultation with industry, a policy of restricting the number of licence holders as a means of improving exporter co-ordination and co-operation. This policy was determined by the Corporation, after a long period of examination of the industry's exporting arrangements at a time when exports of apples and pears have generally been declining.

The Industries Assistance Commission has also recently looked at the industry's export arrangements and, in its August 1985 report on the industry, suggested that the Corporation's export controls be largely removed.

The Government has not accepted the IAC's suggestion on the basis that the Corporation's export policy should be given the chance to work. Under the proposals contained in this Bill the Corporation will be solely responsible for administering the policy in relation to determining the issue of licences. Unsuccessful applicants will continue to have the right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill also provides for a number of amendments of a machinery nature. The most significant of these is to place the requirement on the Corporation that it be subject to the discipline of corporate planning as a means of improving its operations and accountability to industry and Government. These provisions have been included in the legislation of some other primary industry statutory marketing authorities and will as soon as practicable be introduced for the others as part of the recently announced policy relating to these authorities. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the proceedings last night, for the purpose of considering Senator Durack's three amendments together the Committee, by leave, took clauses 4, 6 and 7 together.
