SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 7, clause 5, lines 37 to 39, leave out the clause.

This clause was originally included out of an abundance of caution in order to ensure that certain rules of interpretation in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 would be available in the interpretation of the articles in the Bill of Rights charter part of the legislation. Further consideration has revealed that the clause is really not necessary since the rules in the Acts Interpretation Act apply to all parts of all Acts. Furthermore, it was feared that the presence of the clause might have some unintended effects on the Bill's operation and it was decided that the most appropriate course was simply to delete the clause in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not rise to oppose Senator Gareth Evans's amendment on behalf of the Government. I am not aware of any statement or explanation, apart from the ordinary explanatory memorandum, that the Government has made in regard to its 13 amendments to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. Is there any theme to these amendments, or are they all purely ad hockery and patching up exercises which, one would have thought, the Government has had plenty of time to deal with already?

—I think Senator Durack will well appreciate from his days as Attorney-General that there is minor cleaning up that almost inevitably arises with any Bill of any complexity in the course of its passage. I do not think any of the Government amendments have any substantive effect. The first one we dealt with yesterday was to delete the word `the' before `Schedule' and substitute `Schedule 1'. This clause is purely a formal one, as I have explained. They are all of that kind and we will do our best not to detain the Committee too long as we deal with each of them in a row. I would be happy, in a sense, to deal with them all at once, but I think it probably suits the convenience of everyone, including posterity, if we deal with them in sequence in the appropriate place so that I can explain each time what they are about.

—Senator Evans, I think the draftsman has given you the amendment in a somewhat convoluted way. You are seeking to leave out the whole clause. The simplest way to do that would be to vote against the clause when I put the question that it stand as printed.

—I am not entirely satisfied with the explanation given by the Minister. The Australian Bill of Rights Bill will pass over to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the courts the interpretation of fundamental laws and will give them a very wide degree of discretion. The Minister said that the original purpose of putting in this clause was to ensure that the operation of the Acts Interpretation Act, and presumably of section 15AB of the Acts Interpretation Amendment Act 1984, would apply; that is to say, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the courts would be required in the interpretation of the laws to have regard to a number of things: Those questions that are arising out of this debate; statements that are made by the Minister; votes that are taking place in this chamber; and the explanatory memorandum. I want to know what are those unintended consequences which the Minister fears might occur if this clause is contained in the Bill. The Minister said that one of the reasons this clause is being taken out is that it may well have had some unintended consequences. What are those unintended consequences?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some extravagantly technical point to this effect was apparently made by the Western Australian Solicitor-General; that there might have been some unintended displacement of the operation of section 109 of the Commonwealth Constitution. I confess that I have no idea what the substance of the point was, and if I stop to find out we would be delaying proceedings by about 20 minutes. The short point is that it was an abundance of caution that put it there in the first place. Because of the unusual drafting form that is adopted of separating out the particular provisions and putting them in separate articles of a single section, there was a concern that maybe that would mean that the ordinary principles under the Acts Interpretation Act were inapplicable to those things. I think it is universally acknowledged that it is desirable that the general principles of interpretation be applicable to these clauses. I did not understand Senator Harradine to be saying anything different. Under the circumstances, rather than create other potential for confusion, as people wonder what on earth this provision is about, it seemed desirable simply to delete it.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause negatived.
Clauses 6 and 7 agreed to.
Clause 8 (Australian Bill of Rights).

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —We will deal with this clause article by article.

INTERJECT.PARA: Article 1 (Entitlement to rights and freedoms without distinction).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 8, line 17, after `birth', insert: `, disability'.

The purpose of this amendment is to spell out what might already be contained in the words `or other status'. Indeed, there are some overseas cases which would suggest that the meaning of the words `or other status' includes the word `disability'. I am referring to the case in the Netherlands, of which doubtless the Minister would be aware. It seems to me in that case that to spell out the word `disability' does not do any violence to that clause or run foul of the types of propositions the Minister was making last night about expanding beyond the original intention of the Government and the implementation of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

It is useful to draw out of the meaning of the words `or other status' the word `disability', since when one looks at the range of items which are set down-race, colour, sex, language, religion, politics or other opinion, national or social origin, property and birth-one has ranged through most of the major bases for discrimination within our particular society. There are probably two others, one of which Senator Vigor reminded me of a moment ago, and that is age. The other one, to which we have moved an amendment, is disability. One is acutely aware that in the past few years in Australia disability has lessened as a ground for discrimination. Since the international year dedicated to the disabled, corporations, governments and almost all institutional organisations have directed their attention to the problems of the disabled, from the very low but very practical suggestion of having ramps to the very important suggestion that one would discriminate against someone on the basis that he or she may be severely disabled yet incredibly mentally capable.

Those movements in our society, if one is to take the Government's intention with regard to this Bill, would be enhanced by specifically spelling out that we do not wish in Australia to have any derogation from the rights and freedoms of any individual because he or she is in some way disabled. I think that would be a further contribution to Senator Cooney's suggestion during the second reading debate that the items contained in the Ten Commandments have always been extremely important, but there is no harm in their being put down in tablets of stone. Likewise in this area, if we wish to make these types of comments about very important items such as race, sex and religion, we should also make them about those people who suffer from some disability and who would find encouragement in the Federal Parliament proclaiming that their entitlement before the law and to human rights would in no way be derogated from because of their disability, of whatever kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment for essentially technical reasons, not because of any desire to exclude disability from the categories of prohibited discrimination and not because of any belief that the present clause does not extend to disability-we do believe that it does-but rather because we think the language of the existing International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights ought to be preserved in its entirety in order to better ensure the chances of constitutional survival of this Bill when and if it goes before the High Court of Australia. I think the best way of approaching this question is to get a very clear understanding at the outset as to what Article 1 and Article 4, the other equality clause, are each about. Probably in the drafting and interpretation of Bills of Rights there has been no other area so redolent with confused, woolly thinking and confused, woolly drafting than these questions of equality and non-discrimination. The draftspersons of this Bill have tried very hard to untangle the two separate equality concepts that are involved in the Covenant and to put them in two separate clauses.

SPEECH.PARA: What Article 1 is about is essentially a procedural guarantee rather than a substantive one. Article 1 is a guarantee that everyone in the community, whoever they are, whatever status they happen to have, should be equally subject to the law and equally subject to, and equally able to take advantage of, the rights contained in the Bill of Rights. There should be no discrimination against anyone in the application of the rights and the correlative duties that are set out in the Bill of Rights. Every person is entitled to equality before the law. Everyone is entitled to the human rights and fundamental freedoms set out in this Bill irrespective of distinctions such as-and they are set out-race, colour, sex and so on. So the point about Article 1 is that everyone, whoever they are, is entitled to the fundamental rights and freedoms. That is hardly a surprising statement. We would expect that to be so. There are no categories of outlaw in our society and we would expect everyone in the community, whatever their status and however they might be described, to be subject to the operation of the law in general and this in particular.

When we get to Article 4 it is a quite different equality guarantee and a much more powerful one. It is not merely of formal significance, it is really of substantial significance and it bears a very close resemblance in its likely effect to the equal protection clause of the United States America Bill of Rights. Article 4 says-we can talk about this in more detail when we get to it-that everyone is entitled to be treated equally by the law, whatever kind of law we are talking about, not just that everyone should be equally entitled to the operation of the Bill of Rights and to be equally able to claim protection of the Bill of Rights but that in particular areas of substantive law-whether it is tax law, insurance law, property law, immigration law or law about anything else-everyone is, prima facie, entitled to be treated equally. That of course is not a right which can possibly be enjoyed in an unqualified way because there are all sorts of reasons why the law will in fact need to treat people unequally. This clause and, indeed, all its counterparts elsewhere around the world are qualified accordingly so as to read in effect that the law shall treat everyone the same, unless there are proper and reasonable grounds for treating people differently. That is the point I want to make right at the outset about Article 4 so that its substantive significance, as compared with the essentially procedural significance of Article 1, can be appreciated.

Coming back to Article 1, what we are talking about is not a right to non-discrimination in the traditional sense of the sex discrimination law and the racial discrimination law that we are familiar with, or in the equal protection sense of the United States Constitution. What we are talking about is simply a statement in many ways of the obvious-that everyone, whoever they are, is entitled to have the law at large apply equally to them and to be equally able to rely upon the guarantees contained in the Bill of Rights. Looked at in that way, it becomes less significant as to what one puts in the illustrative list of categories of status that is set out in Article 1. It is unambiguously inclusive in its formulation at the moment. What is being talked about here is irrespective of distinction, such as-I emphasise the words `such as'-race, colour, sex and so on. Then there is the open-ended category at the end-`or other status'. From the very drafting it is absolutely clear that a status such as disability would certainly be the sort of thing that is being here referred to. As Senator Macklin says, there is a case in the European human rights court which makes it clear that disability is such a status for the purpose of an equivalent provision.

The difficulty I have with Senator Macklin's proposition is that if disability is included why not, indeed, include some other categories of status about which other people feel equally strongly? Why not have a reference to age and marital status which is equally clearly, in this context, the kind of thing that ought not to discriminate or distinguish one citizen from another? Why not identify half a dozen other categories of status-legitimacy versus illegitimacy, for example-which distinguish people one from the other? Why not? In a sense it does not matter because this is an open-ended list. It is just illustrative and to add some more illustrations, albeit not in any complete way, would not do any violence to the content of the clause, and from that point of view it is possible to say that one need not be too worried about the Macklin amendment.

This gets me to the final point I want to make. It is a point that I did make strongly last night in another context and will make equally strongly in other contexts during the day; that is that it is tremendously important for those of us in this chamber who want to see a Bill of Rights passed that will be regarded as constitutionally valid that the final legislation bear as close as possible a relationship to the International Covenant as we can achieve. Any variation from the language of the Covenant needs to be understood as stylistic rather than substantive. There are a number of variations which the Government is proposing, but in relation to each of them we will argue that they do not, in any way, change the basic direction of the adherence to the Covenant and the concepts in the Covenant. When, however, wholly new concepts are added, such as was done last night with the extension of the protections of the Bill of Rights away from just protection against government to protections against trade unions and corporations, one is fundamentally changing what the Covenant is about and creating a piece of legislation which bears a conspicuous lack of identity with the Covenant in that respect. If we go on later today to add rights to property, rights to education, or some of the other things that people want to add in, for understandable reasons in each case-I am not contesting that there is a reasonable ground for argument looked at in its own terms-if we go on adding things which are not there in the Covenant and which cannot be justified by reference to the Covenant, we are creating a piece of legislation which is getting further and further away from its parent treaty and in respect of which it becomes harder and harder to argue that the legislation is a good faith attempt to implement and apply domestically the terms of that particular treaty. So far as Opposition senators are concerned, that is exactly what they would like to achieve. I understand that and I am not fussing about that-it is an entirely legitimate political tactic-but for those of us who approach the matter from a different perspective and say `We want a Bill of Rights and we want a Bill of Rights that will withstand constitutional challenge', that is an absolutely disastrous tactic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until we get to Article 3.
—I think in the long run you are just going to have a list of things which are likely to be challengeable. So don't quibble over this one; there's a love.

—All I say to Senator Haines is that, while the temptation is enormous to go on adding baubles to the Christmas tree, there is a very real danger that at some point she will add so many bloody baubles to the tree that it will fall over and she will have nothing left at all except a handful of shiny propositions which she will be terribly pleased about and which have done her no end of good with some constituency or other during the five minutes she has been advancing that particular cause, but which are absolutely disastrous to the long term success of the whole enterprise. I ask her, with as much conviction as I can muster on this occasion, with as much sincerity as I can bring to bear--
—That is not much, is it?

—That is a very great deal, because I have been living with this for a decade or more-to please rethink what she is doing with these various clauses. The amendment before us is a small example. I am not suggesting that in itself it has gigantic substantive significance or that in itself it would be enough to push over the tree. What I am saying is that the cumulative effect of these various variations, add-ons, excursions away from the basic concept and the basic language of the Covenant, are very dangerous indeed. In their entirety they will produce a piece of legislation which runs a very profound and grave risk of being declared to be not a good faith attempt to adopt and apply that Covenant. It is for all those reasons that I indicate that the Government is not prepared to accept this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendment the Australian Democrats have moved. It is really quite unbelievable to hear the Minister say that the Government will not support the inclusion of disabled people in the category of those persons who are entitled to equal rights before the law. It may be that he has some technical legal reasons for taking that position, but I am afraid it will be very difficult to convince Australians in this day and age that the category of disabled persons is not to be given specific recognition in a Bill of Rights. Article 1 lists the traditional bases of equality of people, irrespective of distinctions as to race, colour, sex, language, religion, political opinion, national origin, property or other status. The Democrats say that `disability' should be included in that list. Clearly, everyone-except the Government-would agree with that view.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very good example of the Opposition's criticism of the Government's whole approach to the Bill of Rights and its failure to bring to this Parliament a proper instrument which would give effect to the needs, aspirations and interests of modern Australians, and not just those guarantees that could be agreed upon in the United Nations in 1966, 20 years ago, when interests and concerns may have been similar in many ways, but were not by any means equal to or picking up those interests that Australians have today. Indeed, the matters that the international community wants to emphasise have probably changed dramatically since 1966. Only a few years ago the United Nations promoted the International Year of Disabled Persons, when great attention throughout the world was focused on disabled people. It was a very important matter for people in this country because as a nation and as a society we started to pay much more attention to the problems of disabled people. We have seen many examples of special provisions being made for disabled people that were not made previously. When the Fraser Government set up the Human Rights Commission we paid particular regard to the need for disabled people to be represented directly on the Human Rights Commission. In fact, two members-one of them, I think, has since resigned-of the Human Rights Commission were disabled people and they made a notable contribution to the actual workings of the Human Rights Commission.

In those circumstances, where there is such widespread interest in, concern for and action taken in regard to disabled people, it is quite inappropriate in a document such as this to ignore them and say that they will be treated as being included under `other status', or that there is no need to specify them because there is a general statement to the effect that every person is entitled to equality before the law. If that is the argument, the Article should not list all the other groups of people who may be the victims of discrimination. We know that people have been discriminated against for various reasons and that is why the Article refers to the grounds of race, colour and religion. For heaven's sake, all those groups of people in the past have been denied equality before the law and that is why they are included in the catalogue of people who are entitled to guarantees under the Bill of Rights. Probably it was a lack of understanding that led to disabled people as a group not being thought of as needing this sort of protection. That is no reason why they should not be included in the Article. We in Australia have already recognised this problem and have taken action on it, but we should not start to ignore them or forget about them. They are entitled to be catalogued here in the same manner as the other groups who historically have been disadvantaged in the world, including Australia.

The Government's totally legalistic approach is a disgrace. Presumably this will be its approach all along. We were told last night that we could not protect people against the powers of trade unions or big corporations because the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights does not cover that point. That is what Senator Evans claimed, but I do not agree with him. We will argue that later. If this Parliament is to pass a Bill of Rights which has any meaning or use, it must be relevant to the day and age in which we are considering it, and to the future. What is the good of having a Bill of Rights guaranteed by this Parliament if it is not relevant to the concerns of modern Australians? Fortunately, modern Australians-except, apparently, the Government-are very concerned about the disabled. We should not have a bar of the nonsensical argument we have just heard from Senator Evans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a point about the Government's refusal, on a specious ground, to accept this amendment. It says that to include the word `disabled' in the Article would remove it slightly from the provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. We will have plenty of chances to see that the Government has been very selective in the application of the rights under the Articles of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to the Articles in the Australian Bill of Rights.
—And the wording they use.

—Indeed, the wording, as Senator Haines has said. A further indication as to why the inclusion of the disabled is appropriate in the Australian Bill of Rights is that the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons is a Schedule to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill. Part of the obligation that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is required to discharge under the Human rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill which we passed last night is in respect of and on behalf of disabled persons. I wonder whether the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is looking a little forward--
—Do you mean me or him?

—Yes, I will say `the Attorney-General', if he has given instructions to the Minister not to accept the amendment. I wonder whether the Minister is looking a little further ahead as to what may happen and what amendments may be required as a result of certain statements that he made last night as to the application of clause 3 and the definition of `person'. I wonder whether that applies to the life after birth or the life before birth. He would well know that as a result of what he said it is now necessary for somebody to clarify Article 18-that is the right to life article-and apply it not only to born persons.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 18 relates to the Declaration of the Rights of the Child which, of course, is part of Schedule 3 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill. That schedule, in part, states:
Whereas a child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth . . .

Of course, the Government can see that, if it accedes to this proposition concerning the disabled, it will open the way for somebody to move amendments referring to the provisions of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child which forms part of Schedule 3 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill. What we are doing now, of course, is mentioning the disabled, who are referred to in Schedule 5 of that Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has invited us to adopt his basic argument that the Bill has been designed as closely as possible in line with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and that no amendments should be introduced which would in any way contaminate that Covenant. I have to say two things in that regard. The Government took absolutely no notice of that principle in the designing of this Bill. Where it suited it, it flew wide; where it suited it, it flew narrow. Let me make it perfectly clear-this will contaminate almost every article in the legislation-that this Bill takes little or no notice at all of the various limitations and qualifications that the International Covenant applies. Where it suits the Government, it ignores them altogether; where it suits it, it takes a narrow view.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, if Article 1 of the Australian Bill of Rights is drawn largely from Article 2 of the Covenant-I presume it is, although I think the Minister has drawn upon other articles and asked us to look at them-surely the Minister has no fear at all about what might happen in a court of law. Article 2 of the Covenant says this:

Each State Party to the present Covenant undertakes to respect and to ensure to all individuals within its territory and subject to its jurisdiction the rights recognised in the present Covenant, without distinction of any kind, such as race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status.
The words `without distinction of any kind' are imperative. The collective word `status' is also used in the Article.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.

—The Minister agrees. Therefore, by his agreement, he must agree that he ought to adopt `disability' because that cannot, under any circumstances, in plain language be subject to challenge. The Minister having agreed, presumably the Government will give its support.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet I would like to point out that my great worry is that the Bill has been designed contrary to what the Minister says. Time and time again what is said in the Bill bears no close relationship at all to what is said in the Covenant. For example, no doubt Article 1 will be subject to a great deal of challenge. Lawyers have put to me that insofar as this Article refers to every person enjoying equality before the law-I stress `every person', without qualification-it overlooks the limitations in terms of legal capacity of people such as enemy aliens. Do we give them equality before the law? It also overlooks such people as bankrupts, certified mental incompetents and prisoners. Further, it ignores the fact that the Crown in some circumstances enjoys preferred status.

These absolute facts are known to us. Every one of us knows that there is not, and rightly so, equality before the law in these things in a free society. In my view, and in the view of others, the entitlement to the rights and freedoms guaranteed in Article 1 is better stated in Article 2 of the Covenant on which this entitlement is based. It has been said, and I agree, that in many ways Article 1 is misleading and will do the very thing that the Minister says he wants to avoid. This set of articles will open a Pandora's box of legal challenges.

Senator Macklin's amendment is impeccable and is now recognised as such by the Minister. However, the Covenant fails to make any qualification or distinction at all and then talks about `other status'. Surely a disability is a status in itself. I find the Minister's defence completely unconvincing and I suggest that both sides of the Committee should now support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, the arguments that I would have put have in fact already been put ably by other senators. I would like to follow up the extrapolation of the analogy that the Minister put in respect of a Christmas tree. Quite frankly, the Minister might not get a chance to do very much Christmas tree decorating because he is so busy. Actually, if decorations are put up around the tree reasonably the tree will not fall over.
—If it is balanced.

—Yes, a balanced approach should enable us to keep the tree standing up so that all of our Christmases do not come at once, as the Minister suggested they would. As I suggested, the purpose of the amendment is to spell out something that is contained in our social structure. Senator Durack also raised this point. We are talking about something for Australia. If in fact we had never had or did not currently have problems in respect of people with disabilities being discriminated against, this might be something that we would put aside.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we have taken up this matter rather than some of the others that the Minister has raised is that it is still a major area of discrimination within our society. It is still very difficult for many disabled people to compete on equal terms. Although they may have equal capacity for appropriate employment, it is difficult for them to compete on equal terms. I suggest that those people who either have disabled children or are disabled themselves are very much aware of the many subtle ways in which discrimination occurs. I believe that we are, as it were, taking the Covenant and spelling out something which, as Senator John Carrick has pointed out, is inherent; it is there. So we cannot be doing violence to it. Indeed, I seek a response from the Minister to the legal argument. I cannot see any way in which any of the eminent judges of the High Court would have any concern about its being there. I also cannot see how it will be, as it were, part of those cumulative baubles that are going to tip the tree over. I do not see how they are added together. Although the Minister has explained to me privately, I must admit that I am still relatively confused as to why the High Court would take up this one and others and, as it were, say: `Since there are so many, this implements something different'. I would have thought that the High Court in this instance would do as it did in the Franklin Dam case, which will obviously parallel this one when it goes to the High Court, when the judges picked their way through the legislation and took out clauses and Parts.

I believe that this in no way adds to what is going on. It merely spells out to the Australian community something which the Australian community has already expressed its concern about and is seeking to remedy. Hence, I believe that it cannot do the type of thing the Minister has said it will do. Senator Harradine referred to the fact that the Government-and the Minister acknowledged this-has already made some significant changes in wording. Is he suggesting that the Parliament's adding to the changes that the Government has already made will tip the tree over or is he suggesting that those which the Government has made do not fall into that category? I would be interested in his response to that. As I understand his argument, he said that the changes which the Government had made were exemplifying the philosophy, understanding and intent of the covenant. I would have thought that this amendment is doing precisely the same. I cannot see how this amendment differs from the types of changes that the Government has made to the Bill. I would be interested in the Minister's response to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The further we go in this debate the more we realise that it is just not possible to bring forward a just and comprehensive Bill. Senator Evans has said that he believes that Senator Macklin's amendment in this area is understood and that there is no need for words to be added. I gather that Senator Evans thinks that all those suggestions put forward by Senator Sir John Carrick are also clearly understood. But what about Aboriginal culture? Do we say to Aborigines acting under their own laws that our law will override their cultural laws? I will be interested to hear the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) answer that because, as I see it, this Article would override the cultural laws of many Aboriginal tribes. Is that the intention of the Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond quickly to Senator Walters by saying, as I did in my first contribution, that Article 1 will not have the effect of overriding anything. It is simply a formal statement of a really rather self-evident proposition in a society such as ours; that is to say, there is nobody who is either of too high a station to be above the reach of the law nor anyone of so low a station as to be beyond the reach of the protection of the law. That is really what Article 1 is all about. That is in a sense the answer to Senator Sir John Carrick's point about enemy agents. Article 1 is applicable to enemy agents in the sense that ours is a society that does not acknowledge the right of anybody to lynch an enemy agent without the due process of law. An enemy agent is, of course, subject to discriminatory legal provisions which treat that person differently from other citizens, but at least he is subject to the application of the law with all its different provisions, and that is all that Article 1 is about.

SPEECH.PARA: The sort of point that Senator Walters wants to make about the legitimacy of differential treatment for different groups is better made in the context of Article 4, which is the substantive guarantee of the equal protection of the law, the prima facie right of everyone to have the law operating in exactly the same way as it affects them, subject to reasonable variations. Then we can get into an argument as to what is a reasonable variation for a group such as a cultural minority and so on, but it is not really applicable to Article 1. It is a different point being made.

In respect of Article 1, I accept the basic point of Senator Macklin's argument and indeed Senator Sir John Carrick's argument that there is no substantive change being worked in the operation of Article 1 by adding a reference to disability. I accept, as I hoped I made clear, that the language of Article 1 is unambiguously inclusive. The particular categories there set out are illustrative only and indeed the protection extends to those of all other identifiable statuses. To that extent it does not do great damage to the chances of constitutional survival. It is a small point I am making. I am making it in a much more vigorous way in the context of other changes that are being proposed which--

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it do any more than your changes?

—Maybe not some of them. For example, the business about the right to marry someone of the opposite sex is a change to the language but not a change to the substance. To the extent that this can be characterised as a change to language and not to substance I cannot disagree with the force of the argument. I am not going to stand here making obtuse arguments for the sheer hell of it if a sound, logical point is made by somebody on the other side; I acknowledge it. All I am saying is that if that change of substance is unnecessary to make clear to the courts or anyone else what the real issue is in the language of a particular right, it is undesirable from the point of view of securing the ultimate viability of this legislation that we make linguistic variations for the sheer hell of it.
—To the citizens, not to the court.

—Maybe so, but any linguistic variation has a potentially cumulative effect. It may be a small additional effect in this instance and a much larger effect possibly elsewhere, but any change adds to the impression that this is not a bona fide, good faith attempt to implement in domestic law the language and the concepts of the Covenant. To that extent it is dangerous.

SPEECH.PARA: The other objection, I guess, to adding disability specifically is simply the presentational difficulty that is involved when one is selective in this way. Nobody has advanced a good argument why age or marital status, to take just two additional kinds of status-and there are others that we could quickly think of-should not be added, because they would not change the substance either. Maybe some group out there-the pensioners' lobby perhaps-would be only too delighted to have some reference to age here. I could not disagree if an argument were put on their behalf in exactly the same way as it has been put on behalf of the disabled by Senator Macklin, but it indicates the sort of arbitrary quality of any additions to this list and the undesirability accordingly of making such additions unless there is a strong overriding reason. There is no strong overriding reason. I do not pursue the opposition on behalf of the Government to the point of division because I acknowledge that no really substantive change is involved, but I indicate that we will resist changes of this kind which, in their potentially cumulative effect, ultimately in our view put at risk the status of the Bill.

The final point I would make in relation to the rather down-market contribution of Senator Durack is that, if it needs to be said, the reason for our unwillingness to put the word `disability' in is for the technical reasons I have just been talking about. It has absolutely nothing to do with any lack of respect or enthusiasm on our part for the rights of the disabled. We are second to none in our willingness to act to protect the legitimate rights and interests of the disabled. We have fully accepted the legitimacy of the claims being made. There is no question of any belief on our part that the rights of the disabled are not presently protected by this clause and the reason for opposing this is not any lack of interest, desire, enthusiasm or respect for the position of disabled people. It is simply for the essentially technical reasons I have been trying to articulate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that all honourable senators believe that all wisdom rests in Senator Evans. Despite his assurance that the proposition I put up would be better dealt with when discussing Article 4, I believe that it rests, and that legal opinion says that it rests, in Article 1. We should add the word `culture' to that list of baubles in Article 1 to which Senator Evans referred. There are so many other words we ought to add as baubles to that list that I believe the whole Article is just a shambles. It does not cover the areas that are of concern to the Opposition. While we agree with the Australian Democrats' amendment, I believe that a lot further consideration should be given to other baubles to be hung on that list.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Evans to explain to me why Aboriginal law regarding marriage, for instance, or other cultural pursuits and cultural reasons for their law would not be disadvantaged by Article 1. Does he suggest that all Aboriginal people will have equal protection under Article 1 in any of their cultural disputes? I would be interested in following that argument. Does this Article override the cultural laws of the Aboriginal people? I see that it does because it says that everyone in Australia will have certain rights, irrespective of any distinction such as race-it is underlined very clearly-colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, and so it goes on. How will that Article not override Aboriginal culture in the example I have suggested?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question before the Chair is that the word proposed to be added by Senator Macklin's amendment be added. After that has been dealt with, the whole Article will be open for further debate. I wish to clear that first question with the Committee in an orderly manner. The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the word proposed to be added by Senator Macklin's amendment be added.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short point is that Article 1 is not about the equal operation of the substantive provisions of the law. To the extent that there is any provision about that, it is Article 4. Article 1 is not about the equal protection of the law; Article 1 is about a very different concept-the concept of equality before the law. I know that Senator Walters can be forgiven for confusing them because they have been much confused in many other legislative and constitutional treatments of this issue and in much of the literature. But I think they are separate and distinct concepts and it is very important to separate them. There has been some redrafting of the language of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in terms of the location of these concepts to separate them.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate my view, for better or worse, that this debate about the protection of minority rights and whether the substantive provisions of the law of marriage or anything else should be equally applicable to different minority cultures is a debate that we can better have in the context of Article 4. It is also an issue that is addressed, I remind Senator Walters, quite explicitly by Article 5 of the Bill of Rights, which talks about the rights of minority groups, including particularly the rights to enjoy their own culture. Again, that is a quite explicit statement of the kind of matter and the kind of interest that she has put in issue by her contribution.

What we are talking about, to go back to Article 1, in that clause is a much more generalised protection and one, as I kept saying before, which is an essentially formal protection in a society such as ours. It acknowledges the right of everyone, irrespective of status of any kind, to enjoy the particular rights and freedoms that are set out in the Bill. No category of people is denied any of the rights that are here set out. It is the right of everyone to be equally subject to the operation of the law and the legal system. There is nobody so high in status, for example, a head of government such as President Marcos, whom the law shall not reach; nor is there anyone so lowly in status or so different in status by virtue of cultural characteristics or anything else that the law-the legal system-does not reach or does not touch in that general sense. That is all that Article 1 is about. From that point of view, I would have thought it was an extremely uncontroversial clause. It simply does not give rise to the sorts of issues about which Senator Walters is concerned. There are other clauses that do that, and I will be very happy to debate them when we get to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek clarification on Article 1. As I read it, clause 1 of Article 1 says precisely what clause 2 says. There is almost absolute precision between the two except that the word `enjoyment' creeps into clause 2. If it is important to add to the word `sex' by mentioning `men and women' specifically, let us have another paragraph that refers to people of different colours and other paragraphs that refer to people of different languages, different religions, different politics, et cetera. It seems to me extraordinary that men and women should be picked out. Taking the generics of the definition of the word `sex', one wonders whether children are not important or whether they have a right to be included in a catch-phrase at the back of the Bill? I do not want to appear to be vexatious, but will we have arguments about transvestites? It seems absolutely clear that clause 1 of Article 1 says what clause 2 says.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Sir John Carrick is not being vexatious at all. He would be surprised perhaps to learn that I agree with him completely. In an earlier incarnation, I had a major discussion with the draftsman and miscellaneous other people about this matter on the grounds that the concept in sub-article 2 is exactly the same as that encompassed in sub-article 1. The answer with which I kept being confronted, and that has been the experience of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) too, is that there was in the case of the sex issue an added reason not only politically perhaps to give explicit recognition to men and women to it but also that Article 3 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights does explicitly address this issue when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The States Parties to the present Covenant undertake to ensure the equal right of men and women to the enjoyment of all civil and political rights set forth in the present Covenant.
That is a spectacularly redundant clause, in exactly the same way as--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have all those women's advisers too.

—I appreciate that the honourable senator did not have that problem, with results that are plain to be seen in terms of his Party's present condition in Opposition. I guess it is an early manifestation of international feminism to have this Article separated out and treated in that way. It is redundant and some drafting problems of this kind which recur in the International Covenant are readily acknowledged by the Government, being itself an instrument and the product of this kind of gathering. One of the things that we are trying to do rather than perpetuate some of the confusions and redundancies is streamline the presentation of the Articles. This is one bit of streamlining that we have not accomplished. I think I have explained quite frankly the reasons why. In technical terms, if you like, it is a desire to be seen to be giving explicit effect to Article 3 as well as a generalised guarantee in Article 2 of the Covenant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to add to the tautology of the clause by my remarks. If we are going to use that logic, and if there are any other articles that relate to race, colour, sex or language, and they are abundant, I say that we need the paragraphs I suggested. I put to the Minister more bluntly that what is proposed is something that is very dangerous in a semi-legal document. We are putting in public relations shop windows when it suits us and leaving out other profound matters when it does not suit us. It is a public relations shop window exercise to say that we recognise equality between the sexes. That kind of nonsense does the Government no credit. I believe that paragraph 1 of Article 1 is absolutely adequate, as the Minister says. Indeed, I wonder whether he will use the same logic for every article in the Covenant itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me respond quickly by saying that of course we would be compelled to use that logic were there any other articles like Article 3 which pulled out a specific category and said that in respect of that category such people were entitled to the same rights and freedoms as everyone else, tautological as that may be. The reality is that for one reason or another, maybe the public relations enthusiasms of the drafters of the original Covenant, there is no other clause that I can recall to that effect elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: I further add for the record that I do not accept that we have omitted from the final draft any right of substance in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights itself. Indeed, we have been roundly rubbished by various opponents of the legislation for including some rights such as freedom from slavery and servitude which are in the Covenant clearly, unequivocally and explicitly, but which are thought by some people to have no possible application in Australia today. We have been scrupulous in our desire to pick up all the substantive issues in the Covenant itself, maybe with an excess of caution in terms of picking up explicitly Article 3. I have acknowledged the point as frankly as I can and I do not think that I can take the argument any further.
Article, as amended, agreed to.
Article 2 (Effect of Bill of Rights on existing rights and freedoms).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it stands, Article 2 is quite unsatisfactory. That is why I wish to move amendment (3) standing in the name of the Australian Democrats. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 8, lines 22 to 24, leave out the Article, insert the following Article:
`Nothing in this Bill of Rights shall be taken to diminish, derogate from or prevent the exercise of any right existing apart from this Bill of Rights.'

I believe that the only way in which we can reassure the many Australians who wrote to my colleagues and me and protect many other Australians is to actually make it clear in Article 2 that this particular Bill of Rights is not a prescription for the rights that Australian people have, that it is in fact just a list of items or rights which the Government agrees to give to individuals in the dealings of that Federal Government with those individuals.

We need to take every possible step to encourage the judiciary not to treat the Bill of Rights as a limiting document. We must not allow them to treat it as a prescription or a list of rights which are the only rights available to individuals. We need to reassure people that hard-won rights in relation to which there is no legislation are not thrown out as a result of this Bill of Rights. The Government's proposed wording protects rights or freedoms existing under or recognised by any other law. The problem is that if the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans, is to be consistent in sticking to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights he should really look at Article 2 in Part II of that Covenant, which says:

Where not already provided for by existing legislative or other measures, each State Party to the present Covenant undertakes to take necessary steps, in accordance with its constitutional processes . . .

The Government has translated this into its version of Article 2 but that translation is a piece of legal baffledegab which is sufficient to make me believe that some of the people who wrote to me were justified in their worries. The Government's version says that:
A right or freedom existing under, or recognised by, any other law--
and that is where it finishes-
shall not be taken to have been diminished or derogated from by reason only that the right or freedom is not set out in this Bill of Rights.

Basically this Article 2 does not include the options that are covered by the Constitution, by the common law, by tradition, or by common understanding of the people of Australia. It means that this Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a prescription and that is what I object to. There is no way in which I will vote for a Bill which becomes a prescription of rights for the Australian people and is limiting. It is not enough that we just simply cover the rights under any other law. We need to ensure as much as possible that the Bill of Rights will not cut across present rights and freedoms or their exercise. That is what most people have been worried about. If this is just a Bill of certain rights, it is quite innocuous. It is reasonable for us to protect people against the action of Federal Government bureaucracies. In that case I would support it. But if this is to be a Bill of Rights which is a prescription of the only rights which Australian people have, it is an extremely bad and dangerous document.
I believe that in no way should any rights or freedoms be taken away and the only ones that are guaranteed not to be taken away are those under the law. In this particular case, the Bill of Rights--

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you give us an example of the kind of right not guaranteed by law that you think might be taken away by the Bill of Rights?

—There are examples that have been quoted and I was about to come to some of these. For example, there is the right to own property, which is not mentioned in here. If this is a prescription that right has been denied.
—But you are going to fix that up.

—Yes, we are going to fix that up, we hope. That is why we are moving in that direction. There are a number of other areas where the Minister has said that he has stuck slavishly to the Covenant but where in fact he has not. Take the case of prisoners. If somebody is imprisoned unjustly, under the United Nations Covenant that person will have a claim against the state. Funnily enough, the Government does not want to give people that right here. That certainly has not be carried across. If the Minister is honest in what he says and he intends to slavishly follow the Covenant, he must have the decency to include all those provisions. There is a provision for equality of both partners in a marriage which is considered under the Covenant and which is in no way mentioned in the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. I have digressed from Article 2 because of the Minister's question.

SPEECH.PARA: In this particular case the Bill of Rights is based on the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That Covenant was ratified by the Fraser Government on 13 August 1980, nearly eight years after it was signed. The United Kingdom signed the same Covenant in 1968 and ratified it in 1976. The United States of America signed the ICCPR in 1977. The importance of the Covenant is that it is an international yardstick for human rights. That signatories or parties to that Covenant abuse it is lamentable; however, this cannot be used as an argument for abandoning the Covenant. I would certainly like to support a Bill which introduces it in Australia but I cannot do so while Article 2 remains in the form that it is in now.

Indeed, those who are familiar with the outstanding work of Amnesty International on behalf of prisoners of conscience will recognise the value of the Covenant. Time after time the circumstances of political prisoners are ameliorated because individuals from around the world can point to the rights and freedoms that the authorities have subscribed to by endorsing international covenants such as the ICCPR. It is a duty that we have towards those countries which are worse off in rights than we are to actually support this type of legislation, providing that it does not remove something from our own people. Without such covenants and other international declarations of human rights and government obligations, a lot of prisoners of conscience would not have been released. A lot of people would still be languishing in prison without charge or trial if the international community could not point to the guarantees that had been given and, unfortunately, in a number of countries around the world, are being broken. We are in a better position to make those points and to be taken seriously if our own house is in order. To the extent that we succeed in putting our own house in order and in being able to point to legislative indicators of that, we will be able to show some solidarity with the oppressed people of the world and play a part in fighting human rights abuses.

I believe we could best achieve this position by starting with a basic international covenant on civil and political rights and adding some other rights such as the right to own property. In fact, we are moving to do this later on. We should add those rights that are relevant and appropriate to the Australian people but in some cases may not be relevant to other political systems. The Government has not always kept to the basic wording of the Covenant. It has not taken up all the Articles of the Covenant. This is particularly so in the area of imprisonment and in the matter of propaganda for war. I wonder why. It has not taken up the prohibition of incitement to violence through the advocacy of national, racial or religious hatred. I certainly ask the Minister why these things have been missed out.

I believe that if we are going to subscribe to international covenants we should do so wholeheartedly and not in a piecemeal manner. The same basic human rights standards should apply to State governments and their instrumentalities. We are not taking our rights seriously unless we extend them to the States. All too often we have boards, officials and inspectors with extensive powers and an attitude which readily gives rise to the abuse of these powers. Once we have ratified a covenant of international standing we should not leave escape routes for State governments or anybody else, otherwise we undermine not only--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vigor, you are getting fairly well away from Article 2.

—Mr Chairman, I believe I am right on the point of Article 2. If the Bill is to be taken as a prescription, and that is the way I read Article 2, we will limit and undermine people's rights. I would be prepared to accept this provided our amendment is passed. I was explaining why I consider it to be dangerous to have the existing wording for Article 2.
—Very well, proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I believe that we undermine our credibility if we do not follow those words. As I pointed out, Article 2 in the Bill does not go as far as the Covenant. The Covenant refers to `legislative or other measures'. I say to the Government that if it is not prepared to extend the application of the Bill of Rights to the States, if it is not prepared to accept the extra rights put forward by the Australian Democrats, and if it is not prepared to tighten the guarantee that the Bill will not take away the rights and freedoms presently in existence, which is what Article 2 is about, the Government is not fair dinkum. Under those circumstances I believe I would have no alternative at all but to vote against the Bill of Rights at the third reading. This is an extremely important aspect to me. It is not a prescription. I support the amendment standing in our name, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in this Bill of Rights shall be taken to diminish, derogate from or prevent the exercise of any right existing apart from this Bill.
Honourable senators will note that I have not limited it by using the word `law' or by mentioning any other way in which this right came about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Article 2 points up the total defect in the Bill of Rights Bill. It indicates that the Bill has included a selective list of rights and excluded many others. It shows that the Bill has made its own selection but has left out profoundly important human rights. The Government argues that it has built these under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights from which the head of power is drawn. The Government has relied on this head of power, but, in this particular case and in no others it has not gone on to search for any other heads of power. I have reminded the Senate in the past that the Government has not been reluctant in any way to look to treaty powers. Indeed, it is one great argument within the Federal system of government that one could virtually destroy the sovereignty of the States by invoking treaty powers.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) that a former Attorney-General of Labor persuasion was willing to suggest that he should use the international treaty on migratory birds in order to prevent the State of New South Wales allowing industrial development at Towra Point on the southern end of Botany Bay, on the basis that migratory swallows from Russia and Japan paused at Towra Point on their way to the Antarctic. If we are looking at treaty powers-that is what this clause 8 is based on-then I have to say that they have no difficulty with migratory swallows but they have great difficulty today in looking for heads of power to find fundamental rights such as the right to private property, the right to pursue the employment of one's choice, the right to seek an independent school, and the right to protection of the unborn. These are terribly and fundamentally important rights. There is nothing in this clause that protects corporations, nothing that protects freedom of speech in terms of the media. This clause shows the absolute fundamentals.

It is no use the Government saying that it is introducing the clause with the apologia saying: `If we have left something out do not think that we have not thought of that and we want to protect it'. If the Government wanted to protect those things it has excluded, why did it not then find a protection for the things it has now excluded? The reason is very simple: The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights was a communist and socialist compromise within the United Nations. The fact of the matter was that no such covenant could be brought about without the support of socialist, communist and many totalitarian states. What happened with this Covenant was that there was a narrow compromise to encompass those things. For Australia to attempt to build in a democratic system a Bill of Rights based on a covenant which was a narrow and very unsatisfactory compromise is a nonsense situation. It fails to understand the very spirit of Australia, and therefore clause 2 in itself actually is a reason for rejection of the whole Bill.

I sympathise with Senator Vigor in his arguments. My trouble is that I do not believe that his amendment is effective in any way at law or that it would achieve any of those things he sets out. Whilst I may not support Senator Vigor in regard to the amendment itself, let me say that everybody in the Australian community should understand what this means. A selection and a rejection indicate a frame of mind. They do not indicate the narrowness of a head of power. How could any socialist government, a Whitlam or a Hawke government, confess to the Senate that it was shy of using the wide treaty powers? After all, such governments have always been keen to open the Constitution as wide as possible. Indeed, it is not the lack of heads of power that denies the Government all the interesting things which will be the journey through the other Articles, it is that is has made its own selection and said: `This is what we regard as important. The others are not important. We will put in a catch thing like that repetition of the men and women clause in Article 1 because it will look good as part of the shop window. Let it be understood that if we have left something out, that does not mean that we do not think much of it; it has to be protected'. That is a nonsense situation.

In my view the clause itself is a disgrace. For example, I omitted to say that the International Covenant would not have tolerated freedom not to associate, freedom not to join a trade union. Of course, that freedom is not expressed in this Bill of Rights. Time and again what we have done here is to build a Bill of Rights based on what totalitarian states, who were then the majority in the United Nations, conceived as the environment for their rights. I do not believe that we can make any kind of amendment that would satisfy this because it is a genetic defect. It is inherent in the Bill itself. It is, if you like, a chromosomae defect.

TALK.START.PARA: —A mutation.

—Yes, a mutation in itself. We cannot make this Bill better by altering this clause. One of the dangers when we have a devised Bill like this in which we elect to have a firm number of rights but leave others out is that we delimit the rights that we prescribe. By prescribing rights we are delimiting them. If anyone has any doubts about that, the very testing of any one of those rights in the High Court of Australia will produce a decision which puts a corral around them and delimits them. In a free society we should not be going about putting in bondage our social, ethical and moral views. So we delimit what we have said and we are in grave danger of diminishing what we have not said. We are in grave danger of saying that this society does not believe in these kinds of situations at all. It has been said by others that we are picking a few rights, not even the most fundamentally important ones. I have mentioned those rights. After all, an essential freedom in a free society is built around the right to possess property, the right to own, the right to acquire, the right to build a family around possessions and so on. The right to the protection of life, for example, is fundamental. There is the right to associate or not to associate, the right of corporations to protection, the right of the media to protection in terms of freedom. These are not listed in the Bill at all. The Government has not only fossilised, as others better than I have said, a series of rights that it has chosen; it has shown a diminution of the other rights by their rejection.

SPEECH.PARA: Let not anybody from the Government say to us that it has not got heads of power for this. I will be delighted if it tells us that it is willing to recognise that international treaties ought not to be a skylight through which the limitations of the Australian Constitution could escape. I repeat, one should keep in mind the background: When the Commonwealth Constitution was agreed to in 1901 the five subscribing States believed that they were giving only absolutely limited and prescribed powers to the Commonwealth, that the Commonwealth could not go beyond that ceiling and that the States had all the residual powers. They never dreamed that by giving the external affairs power under section 51 the making of treaties, internationally, would give the powers to permeate through virtually every aspect of Australian society. So I do not want to hear from the Government the plea that we have to keep this under the International Covenant itself. In any case, if the Government had wanted to entrench these things it could have had a Commonwealth-State meeting of Ministers and Premiers. It could have got an understanding, if it had wanted to, about the great protections that were needed. It did not need to seek heads of powers. It could have got things by way of ministerial councils, as has happened in a thousand different ways before, but it sought not to do that.

The important thing is that the socialist Government has its blueprint on this Bill. This Bill, by what it says and leaves unsaid, describes the Government. It describes the Hawke Government as a government that regards these particular powers and rights as prescriptive and limited, and the ones that have been left out as not being of sufficient merit to come into it. I do not believe that any kind of amendment is going to improve Article 2. It is the defect in the whole Bill of Rights. It is the fundamental reason why at the third reading stage every senator who believes in the true freedom of the Australian people should reject the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to untangle some of the threads that have been set running in the debate so far. It seems to me that there are two separate issues that have been addressed in various ways in Senator Vigor's and Senator Sir John Carrick's contributions. One is the question as to what this clause is all about and how it fits into the general framework of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. There is a second question as to the adequacy or otherwise of the drafting of the clause to achieve its objective. On the first point let me say just this: There is no question of this Bill of Rights ever being intended to be a complete compendium of all the rights which are presently enjoyed by Australians or claimed by Australians; that is to say, all the rights which presently exist under law, whether by way of legislation or common law; rights which are acclaimed to exist; and rights which may be recognised in the sense of being the subject of international treaties but not yet treaties which are translated into domestic law. There is a whole variety of rights of that kind, of various characters, actual and claimed, which do exist or which might be identified. Not all of them by any means were ever intended to be in this particular Bill of Rights. What this Bill of Rights is about is an attempt to pick up and apply as domestic law the particular set of civil and political rights that are set out in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest it be thought by Senator Sir John Carrick's reiteration of this point that this is somehow a narrow or confined list, let me just remind honourable senators of the kind of ground that is covered in the international Covenant and is covered in our charter: Equal protection of the law, rights of minority groups, right of participation in public life, freedom of expression, freedom of thought and conscience, freedom to have or adopt a religion or belief, right of peaceful assembly, freedom of association, right to protection of privacy in the family from arbitrary interference and other rights associated with the protection of the family at law-the right to marry and to found a family, rights of the child-and freedom of movement rights of persons in Australia and to enter and leave Australia. There is a series of rights relating to life, liberty and the criminal process: The right to life as such; the right to liberty and security of the person; the right not to be held in slavery or servitude; the right to be informed of the reason for one's arrest and of charges; the right to consult a lawyer and to remain silent; rights in relation to hearings, release and trial; the right to test the lawfulness of detention-the traditional habeas corpus; the presumption of innocence; the right to a fair hearing; the rights of the accused relating to trial; rights in relation to non-retrospectivity, review of conviction and sentence; no trial or punishment for the same offence; rights when imprisoned, when deprived of liberty; and rights in relation to no torture or inhuman treatment and no experimentation without consent. That is what this Bill is about. It is enormously diverse in the array of things that it covers, but there are common linking threads. They all relate in one way or another to basic political and civil rights. They are not necessarily even exhaustive of that list of civil and political rights that many of us might want to add to, but they are nonetheless a coherent whole.

I am fascinated with Senator Sir John Carrick's suggestion, in fact his invitation, to wander at large around possible heads of Commonwealth power with a shopping bag to find heads of power which might support a further excursion of Commonwealth legislative intervention in this area. That is not a course which Senator Sir John Carrick normally is prone to recommend. It may have been an available course, but it is not one the Commonwealth has chosen to follow in this instance. There are many other kinds of rights which may or may not fit within this broad category of political and civil rights which are already well protected by law. The right to property is one very good example of that. It is protected at the Commonwealth level by constitutional protection as well as legislation concerning non-compulsory acquisition without compensation. It is protected at the State and Territory level, not at a constitutional guarantee level but certainly by legislation again guaranteeing non-compulsory acquisition without appropriate compensation. There are lots of rights of that kind protected by legislation or by common law which we have not picked up.

There is a whole panoply of rights set out in the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights which have been deliberately omitted from this exercise. Not for want of constitutional power, because that is readily there, did we choose to hang our hats on that particular international treaty to which we are a party, but it is simply not appropriate to treat those rights in the same way as we treat these other rights, all of which are capable of legal protection through the agencies of the courts and similar instrumentalities in a way that is simply not the case for that category of social, economic and cultural rights-the rights to education, employment and so on-which tend to get confused so often in the debate. They are essentially rights of a kind that are best protected by the devotion of adequate and appropriate government resources. They are not the sorts of things we can run litigation about.
Consideration interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Grimes left today to represent the Government at the funeral of the late Prime Minister of Sweden, Mr Olof Palme. He will return to Australia on 22 March after attending a meeting of the Socialist International in Oslo. The Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, will be Acting Minister for Community Services in Senator Grimes's absence. All questions in this chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Grimes, either in relation to his portfolio or those he represents, should be addressed to Senator Ryan. Any queries in relation to the management of Government Business in the Senate should be directed to me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Is it true that the document entitled `1986-87 Budget Strategy', which was leaked to the Sydney Morning Herald last week, foreshadows a tax take of $59.7 billion, which is $1.1 billion above the Budget estimate and almost 14 per cent higher than last year? If the Minister does not wish to answer a question about a leaked document, I ask him in his capacity as Minister for Finance whether it is a fact, on the information presently available to the Government, that it appears that there will be a tax take of $57.9 billion this year, which is $1.1 billion above the Budget estimate and almost 14 per cent higher than last year. Given this projected revenue outcome, how does the Government propose to meet the Prime Minister's renewed commitment of yesterday to the trilogy as it affects taxation revenues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly will not comment on documents which have been published and are claimed to be authentic government documents. I will answer the substance of the questions. Of course, all of these figures will be subject to substantial changes over the course of the next few months, but the present expectations are that receipts will be close to $1 billion-less than $1 billion, but close to $1 billion-above the Budget estimate. That does not conflict in any way with the trilogy commitment given by the Prime Minister prior to the 1984 election because the relevant leg of the trilogy was that taxation revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product would not on average during the term of this Parliament be higher than it was in 1984-85.

ANSWER.PARA: Even if one likes to adopt a more strict definition-that it will not be higher in any of those years-the present estimate of tax revenue as a proportion of GDP is very much the same. The principal reason to this stage for the revenue being higher was increases in Bass Strait oil production, although because of the lower price which will apply from 1 March the total oil revenues will be within the Budget estimates.
