TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to President Reagan's current efforts to raise Congressional support for $US100m in mostly military aid for the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. In view of the Sandinista Government's widely approved human rights record, especially in the areas of health, education and the general area of human rights, as well as its policy of a commitment to a mixed economy and in view of the fact that the so-called freedom fighters have a record of being nothing more than disorganised, cold-blooded butchers, I ask: What action is the Australian Government taking to express its objection to any further intrusion by the United States Administration in the affairs of this small Central American country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The President and senior members of the United States Administration have recently made statements underlying their determination to see the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua replaced by supporting the Contras who are engaged in domestic insurgency, mostly from safe havens in neighbouring Honduras. Moreover, the United States Secretary of State, Mr George Shultz, has hinted at the use of United States marines. These statements have been made in the context, as Senator Bolkus said, of seeking support for a request to the United States Congress for approval to spend $US100m on civil and military aid to the Contras over the next 18 months, succeeding the $US27m limited to non-lethal aid which the approved for the 12 months ending on 31 March. So far it is the case that Congressional consideration of the request has not been totally sympathetic to the Administration.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has been very closely watching developments in Central America and continues to believe that military action will not solve the problems of the region. The supply of military aid to the Contras, in addition to the non-lethal aid they already receive, can in our view only increase tension there and add an unwelcome complication to the difficult task of the Contadora countries and their supporters in working towards a negotiated solution of conflicts in the region.

On the question of human rights, it has to be said that the record of the Contras is atrocious and does not give cause for confidence in their democratic credentials. Mr Hayden has previously expressed some disappointment over the Sandinistas' disrespect for the legitimate rights of their political opponents in Nicaragua and that also has to be taken into the balance in any judgment about this area. As to the last part of the question, as in the past, the Australian Government will make known to the United States its concerns on Central American issues where appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to the Press conference which the Minister had with the Treasurer on 24 February at which the Government's new policies on oil and oil tax- ation were announced. I remind the Senate that both the Minister and the Treasurer agreed that the new oil tax introduced to offset the loss in Government revenues from falling world oil prices would be reduced if oil prices increased in the future. Subsequent to the Press conference the Minister said that appropriate adjustments will be made only if significant rises occur in world oil prices. What rise in world oil prices will be required to trigger a reduction in the new excise that is about to be imposed? How will that adjustment to the excise be determined?

—In the immediate future it appears that we are more likely to face a fall in world oil prices compared with the 1 March import parity price than a rise, but it remains the case that the Government is committed not to extracting any windfall benefits from the product excise imposed by way of revenue compensation at the time of the 1 March IPP increase. I said that it was the Government's position that the excise rate would be adjusted in response to any significant change in the IPP. That of course applies not only in relation to a move up but also a move down. It may well be the case that if oil prices drop by an obviously insignificant amount there would be no particular view within the Government that the product excise should rise by an equally insignificant amount to cope with that.
—May or may not be.

—It may not be the case that we would take the view that the product excise should rise to cope. A lot depends, of course, on what counts as an insignificant change, but I simply make the point that we have been quite straight forward in saying that this is a revenue compensation exercise; it is not a revenue acquisition exercise and we would, as indeed I said at that Press conference, be in considerable difficulty justifying our action if we acted in such a way as to treat the product exercise we have added on this occasion as cash in hand in the event that product prices went up. We just simply have no desire to act in that particular way and we will make the adjustments accordingly. A precise mechanism has not been worked out for making those adjustments, but I imagine that it will continue to be the notification in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and through tabling in the House of Representatives in the usual way. There is no particular mystery about that mechanism. It has been adopted in the past and will, no doubt, be adopted in the future, with the appropriate excise rate being struck in accordance with the principles I have already indicated.

—I ask a supplementary question. That was an interesting answer but I really asked whether the Minister could give some indication of, to use his favourite phrase, the order of magnitude required before this adjustment process could be introduced? What does he mean by a significant rise in world oil prices or, for that matter, a significant loss, I suppose?

—Senator Durack is requesting me to quantify something that at this stage I am not in a position to quantify. It is a matter for Government decision. What I am in a position to do is reiterate the principles in which both Mr Keating and I stated the Government's position at the time of that Press conference, and those principles, which I firmly reiterate now, are that we will not make any windfall gains out of the product excise; we will not hang on to product excise except perhaps for some trivial gain or we will relinquish the possibility of some trivial gain in the event of a downward shift, because of all the administrative complications and the machinery complications that are involved in changing the excise rate right across the nation. There would obviously have to be a reasonably significant move in order to justify some change to all of those rates and all the huge administrative cost involved in changing the rate. But the principle remains the same. We have made the commitment to take product excise only by way of partial compensation for the loss of crude oil excise and, to respond to the sorts of things Senator Siddons has been saying to us publicly, we do not intend to make any windfall gains out of that. I mention finally that the trilogy is itself a constraint on windfall gains. We cannot make some substantial addition to revenue without running headlong into the discipline imposed by the trilogy on the revenue side. So not only is there no intention to do so and not only have we said we will not in the context of oil policy but we are also constrained by the additional discipline of the trilogy commitment to stop us doing so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer him to allegations in a media release on 9 March by the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Tim Fischer, that the Government is contemplating imposing an assets test on war disability pensions. Is there any substance to this allegation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we come up towards the Budget, there will be a great deal of conjecture and controversy about changes in government policy in respect to a whole range of issues affecting every Minister. I am somewhat surprised that Mr Fischer would put out a Press statement that suggests that the Government was seriously contemplating the establishment of an assets test for disability or totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners. Firstly, I refute that. There is no truth in that suggestion. I do not know where he got that information from and I find it difficult to comprehend why a person I have been working with since he was appointed by the Leader of the Opposition as the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs would make a public statement without checking the facts with me, my office or the Department of Veterans' Affairs. He certainly would have been reassured that the Government does not contemplate any such proposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government accepts, as indeed the Opposition when in government accepted, that disability pensions are compensation for illness or disabilities arising out of war service and, therefore, compensation should not, in any way, be associated with any sort of test. A person may be a millionaire or have limited means. If he is injured in an accident the court has no regard to his station in life; it has regard to whether he should receive compensation, and that is the position of a government. However, since Mr Fischer made that statement and it received some publicity, a number of veterans' organisations, including the TPI congress that I was at this morning, have expressed concern because it does create unnecessary anxiety and concern and people react, particularly veterans in the 70- to 80-year bracket. Whilst every Minister in one way or another is being asked by the Government to effect savings, some areas are completely sacrosanct. Disability pensions will not be affected. No cuts will be made in this or any other Budget of the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health inform the Senate of the effect of a threat by the Australian Medical Association not to accept Medicare benefits as full payment for the treatment of pensioners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The AMA's threat not to accept Medicare benefits as full payment would place an unreasonable financial burden on the most disadvantaged group in the community. Many of the sick and aged would either not seek medical care or would become outpatients at public hospitals. Data from the Medicare payment system indicates that over half of all general practitioners generate more than $50,000 in fees for Medicare-related services. Those in full time practice receive an average of about $90,000 per year, and in addition receive extra income from workers compensation and third party patients and from visiting medical officer or sessional arrangements with hospitals.

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1970, medical benefit fee schedules have risen by 314.3 per cent, while the consumer price index has risen by only 298.6 per cent. Clearly, medical practitioner fees have not been eroded over the past 15 years. In 1970 pensioners and other disadvantaged persons comprised 8.3 per cent of the population compared with 14.9 per cent in 1985. In the same period, the number of doctors in the population has doubled. The claims by the AMA that the increasing number of pensioners is affecting their income must therefore be seen as fallacious. It is a longstanding tradition among doctors that pensioners are not charged more than the Medicare rebate. The AMA seems to feel that doctors are owed a living by the community and that governments and the public should guarantee the incomes of their ever increasing numbers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BROKEN HILL PROPRIETARY CO. LTD: TAKEOVER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the event of Mr Holmes a Court making a successful bid for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd, what are the implications for investment in Australia from those who have sold their shares in BHP? Is the Government worried that surplus funds of investors could be taken off-shore, or is the Government confident that allowing companies imputation will ensure that these funds are invested in Australian industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is believed that about 20 or 25 per cent of BHP shares are currently owned by overseas investors. If they are sold, one would expect that the money would very likely go off-shore. Bell Resources Ltd has made a partial bid for BHP shares, some of which is in the form of cash and/or shares in Bell. Depending on the extent to which either of those offers is taken up, that will also affect the flow of funds either within Australia or between Australia and overseas. It is unclear whether any Australian resident BHP shareholders would choose to place the proceeds of any share sales off-shore.

ANSWER.PARA: Two general points can be made. Firstly, investors make the choice as to where to place their funds, having regard to relative rates of return, exchange rate risks, and so on. Any current investor in BHP shares is able to sell at any time and acquire assets elsewhere. Therefore, there is no reason to assume that acceptance of the Bell Resources bid will lead to any significant change in the existing preference for local versus overseas investment.

Secondly, under a floating exchange rate any funds leaving Australia must be matched by funds coming in, unless, in the very short term, reserves could be run down. In the longer term, funds moving out of Australia must be matched in some way by funds moving in. The exchange rate and interest rate differentials change to see that that balance is maintained. For all those reasons it is not clear whether the partial takeover, if it is accepted, would have significant effects on the overall portfolio choice between local and foreign securities. The Government decided on that account that there is not a basis for any government intervention in the takeover.

—The honourable senator asks `Why not?'. Well, honourable senators opposite say that they do not want to have a large bureaucracy. If they want somebody from the Department of Finance looking over the shoulder of everybody else in the Public Service who is writing a cheque or authorising a payment, we would need to have a Department of Finance about the same size as the rest of the Public Service, a prospect which has induced groans from some of my colleagues. Until that report has been completed I do not believe it would be appropriate for me to make any further comment.

—I ask a supplementary question. In respect of the latter part of the answer, I did not ask the Minister to give us any information relating to the police investigations. I asked about the Government's investigation. In regard to the first part of the Minister's answer, I ask: Is the Minister not aware that it is stated on page 9 of the Commonwealth Government Directory that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has responsibility to monitor CEP programs; and that it is stated on page 3 that the Department of Finance, the Minister's own Department, has responsibility for monitoring staffing and expenditure in `(b) employment and industrial relations programs and the overseeing of the financial and human resources budgets relating to these matters'?

—I do not know what I am supposed to say to that. I do not know the Commonwealth Government Directory off by heart so I would not be able to comment on what Senator Lewis has just quoted. In response to the earlier part of the supplementary question, allegations have been made in the Bulletin about alleged impropriety and so on and they are being investigated by the police.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, follows the recent reply he gave about disability cuts. He said that there would not be any. However, as far as my Department is concerned, I do not believe it would be possible to make the sorts of savings that have been suggested in some Press statement or release or leaked document or whatever. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate would be aware that the wealthy shipping combines over many years have been using the process of a flag of convenience to deny legitimate wages and conditions to seamen and that this has been a matter of grave concern to trade unions in Australia and, for that matter, in many countries. DEBATE.TITLE: ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT: ENVIRONMENT COMMITTEE AT MINISTERIAL LEVEL

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Australian Delegation to Third Meeting

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Senate has before it the report of a meeting of Environment Ministers of those countries which are members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. This is an important report because this meeting was only the third of its kind at ministerial level within the OECD. The important thing about this report is the extent to which it outlines the views taken by the Australian delegation leader, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, presumably on behalf of the Government outlining what is seen as the balance and the link between employment and the Environment. On page 24 of the report is the text of Mr Willis's address to the conference. He begins by saying:
Australia shares the view of many countries that the major environmental challenge we face over the next decade is the wise management of national resources for sustainable economic growth.

I believe that is a correct appreciation of the major challenge facing Australia and OECD countries in the management of the natural environment. Elsewhere in his speech, Mr Willis draws attention to the adoption of the national conservation strategy in Australia. I note once again the way in which the present Government has indicated its support for the national conservation strategy simply to draw attention to the fact that this strategy was originally pioneered by the Fraser Administration and was, in fact, first formally adopted by that Liberal Government.

The report is also important in terms of indicating the necessity within any one country, as a member of the OECD, to achieve what is referred to in the report as `policy complementary'. It seems to me that, in looking at the whole range of environmental issues which come before a government, there are very often contradictory policies being pursued. For example, some of our taxation policies are occasionally quite at variance with the perceived environmental objectives of government. It has only been in recent years that an attempt has been made to integrate those policies in terms of development, environment protection, taxation and other related issues.

The final point which I wish to make arising from the report is an indication of the extent to which for the first time there appears to be a far more broadly based appreciation of the need for international co-operation to deal with certain environmental matters. The report draws particular attention to the question of acid rain, sulphur dioxide pollution, which is a major problem in both Europe and North America. The interesting point about this is that the people who are suffering in North America are, by and large, the Canadians but the people responsible for the problem are those in the United States of America. The people suffering in Europe tend to be the Swedes and the people responsible for their problem are primarily the British and the Germans. It is only by the promotion of effective international agreements and arrangements dealing with the problems of environmental degradation and the threats to the environment which spread across whole continental land masses that these significant issues can be addressed. I am glad to see that at this ministerial meeting of the OECD attention was paid to that matter. At this stage it is not a major problem as far as Australia is concerned, other than in the area of the effects of French nuclear testing in the region. However, it is likely to have some effect as far as industrial development in Australia is concerned in terms of relationships with our neighbours to the immediate north.

I think the report is a good one. It raises a number of significant issues which are of concern to Australia. I hope that arising out of the ministerial level meeting Australia will place itself in a position to learn from some of the lessons which have become apparent in Europe and North America and will not find itself repeating some of the mistakes made by national governments in those other continents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too hope that Australia does not make the same mistakes as other countries have made, but it looks as though we are going to. The third meeting of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Environment Committee at ministerial level was not attended by our Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen. It was attended by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ralph Willis. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Review of Defence Project Management

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Senator Maguire:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Joint Committee of Public Accounts investigation of HMAS Tobruk, report No. 223, indicated that there were serious deficiencies with the Department of Defence, particularly in relation to project management. We believed that these deficiencies required a more thorough investigation. Together with the Auditor-General's report of September 1983, which also highlighted unsatisfactory findings on a significant number of major defence projects, there appeared to be sufficient grounds for a major inquiry. The Committee therefore considered that it was necessary to examine the totality of activities associated with the acquisition of major defence equipment, even down to specific brands of equipment and also to examine in detail 16 individual projects in order to review the efficiency and effectiveness of defence project management systems.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, it is with regrettable concern that we have to report the Committee's findings that of the 16 projects examined 11 may fail to be completed in time, to budget or to technical requirements. In three projects, the United States built frigates, the F111A attrition aircraft replacement and the Rapier, the major equipment items entered service requiring major modifications or the resolution of significant technical problems. I could go on for perhaps 10 minutes itemising the glaring deficiencies in our defence equipment. It is nothing short of disgraceful. In fact, the Committee made 68 recommendations with the object of improving effectiveness, efficiency and accountability of defence project management. I am pleased to note that the Government has already accepted a great number of these recommendations.

I believe that the report is a further reflection of the malaise within the defence forces and I think gives rise to a growing concern within the community about Australia's ability to defend itself even from minor attack. I find it also of considerable concern that this country is becoming far too locked in to dependence on the technology of a particular power. I think this could lead to an embarrassing situation if and when the interests of that country were at variance with our own. I am also reminded of instances during the Vietnam war when Australian forces were without adequate spares or ammunition because France and Sweden espoused different views and philosophies from our own at that time. Too great a proportion of our defence procurement comes from overseas. Surely it is time we started to develop our own technology instead of shipping it in from foreign powers.

Investigations have also revealed a lack of adequate technical training on board ships. Recent examples show that there is an inadequate number or even a lack of maintenance manuals carried on board ships, particularly when they are at sea. More often than not there is not even adequate knowledge amongst the trained personnel to contend with practical problems or difficulties. It is unfortunate that Australia lost four seamen in recent years because of the discharge of lethal gases. Three of these seamen were on board the Stalwart and Kenneth Dax was on the Tobruk. I believe a greater knowledge of the equipment and its problems and better training in the use of technology could stop more lives being lost in the future.

Decision-making within the Department, I believe, leaves a lot to be desired. Costly modifications have had to be made to imported equipment, some of which should have been incorporated during the construction. Take, for example, the case of the FFG frigate. It is appalling that the US Navy knew in September 1976 that modifications would have to be made to accommodate the Sikorsky Seahawk helicopter. Yet the Royal Australian Navy did not analyse the economic feasibility of incorporating the modifications during the construction of any FFGs prior to 1979. Furthermore, it did not see the necessity for the modifications being made to US FFGs even though plans and specifications were received by the RAN late in 1979. As a result, decisions recently made to incorporate these necessary modifications, post-delivery will cost an estimated $51m. The Committee found it hard to accept that there should have been such a costly delay in incorporating these modifications. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on defence procurement. We are worse off in this country in relation to defence than we were in September 1939. One has only to look at officer resignations, which are now running at a record level, and look at the total state of disarray of the reserves, particularly the Army Reserve, where the numbers are down because people have left in their droves. The Reserve has no role at all despite a general nebulous concept that it be integrated with the Army.

SPEECH.PARA: We have some good equipment coming on line, but we have nowhere near enough and it does not cover a wide enough range of equipment. We have no ready reaction capability. The best we can do is to put a company group somewhere close by with seven days notification. That company group would be armed with packs and rifles, entirely devoid of transport, reconnaissance capability or any anti-armour capability. It is absolutely meaningless from a defence point of view. This has partly come about because of the policy of continental defence that the Australian Labor Party follows. It believes that Australia only needs to be defended against attacks against the mainland and, therefore, we have no capacity to preserve the peace and stability of our region, which really is the key to our security. We should be able to put forces, whether they are land, sea or air, into the regions of the Association of South East Asian Nations if they are under attack, to support them. Of course, this all comes from the no threat doctrine which the Labor Party loves. It is not so many years ago under another Labor Government that we had talk of no threat for 15 years. While the present Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) does not go around saying that, implicit in everything that the Department does and every statement from this Government in relation to defence is the no threat doctrine. I will be very surprised if when the report of Mr Dibb comes out we do not find that the no threat doctrine is enshrined once more in holy writ.

In recent times as evidence of this inability to defend Australia we have had the release of the Newcastle-Geelong line. The Labor Party is prepared to give up everything north of the line from Newcastle to Geelong. That is how seriously it takes this problem of defence. It is reminiscent of the Brisbane line of an earlier Labor Government in 1942. As Senator Sir John Carrick drew to my attention at lunch-time, that fits in very well with Prime Minister Curtin's statement which was recorded in Hansard only eight months before the start of World War II that there was no threat facing Australia at all. It is a pity he did not tell those servicemen who went out and died defending the country through the ensuing five years.

I think the report of the Public Accounts Committee is an excellent report. There are detailed points with which I disagree. I think the Committee could have taken a slightly broader view, but overall it is an excellent report and it draws graphically to the attention of the public the deficiencies in the way we buy equipment in this country. I think it is a reflection on the incompetence of the Government that a committee of the Parliament had to find this out. After three years of Labor government, we have seen a decline in the management of the procurement of defence equipment. Minister Beazley and the Cabinet have sat there while this situation has deteriorated all around them. It has been due to the hard work of Senator Georges and other people with high ideals in the Labor Party, Liberal Party and National Party that this report has been made.

It is important that we get value for our money. At present we are spending 25.9 per cent of a very meagre defence vote on capital equipment. If we go back only a couple of years to 1982-83, the percentage of the vote was 17.4 per cent. Because we have gone up to 25.9 per cent of a meagre budget-I make no secret, as I have said on previous occasions here, that we should be spending twice as much on defence as we do-it becomes even more crucial that we get value for that money. Because we are spending so much on capital equipment, we have got cuts in the numbers of service personnel and in operational training. This report deals with the sorry history of acquisitions of equipment in the immediate past. It is not true to say that all is gloom. There have been some very successful projects managed by the Department of Defence, but regrettably they have been outstripped by the great number of unsuccessful ones. The classic successful one, of course, was the submarine weapons update program performed by Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd on the Oberon boats where we went into an entirely new field of weapons sensors for the submarines. This was developed in Australia and was completed on time and on budget. I think the way the acquisition program of the F18 was managed was very successful. On a different plane, the Army project Raven-the concept of which worked up a new specification for radios-was something that was done within Australia and was done very successfully.

The disasters that have taken place are legion. Regrettably most of them are related to the Navy. On Fremantle class ships, the tenders called for a design which had been proven in service. We bought a boat that had never been built. It turned out to be 25 tonnes overweight. As the incident with HMAS Wollongong demonstrated some months ago, it was a design which simply lacks hull integrity. If that ship had not stuck fast on the rocks it would have sunk. This is an inadequate design feature in the Fremantle class. The bulkheads will not withstand the water pressure; they are not watertight and they are not airtight. Piping and ventilation runs go through them. This is a warship; it is not a yacht. It does not have the required hull integrity. The question that can be asked by this Committee and this Parliament is: Why was that design ever accepted?

The Committee deals at great length with HMAS Success, which is a very ironical name for one of the great programs of mismanagement by the Department. This Parliament was told that the ship would be built to a fixed price contract of $68m and it ended up costing pretty close to $200m. It is fair to say that it is a rather botched up design. While it will fulfil its role, it will not fulfil it in the way which was intended.

The report also deals with the purchase of the new small arms for the Australian Army. I would like to make two points about this. The Army has decided to move from the FN/SLR rifle with a calibre of 7.62 mm to a calibre of 5.56 mm, which in imperial terms is .22 of an inch calibre. I think a very good argument can be made for retaining the heavier calibre because a weapon that is to be used in Australian conditions, and in most of the conditions in which we would be operating, is needed to engage targets at a considerably longer range than the close contact jungle patrolling for which the lighter calibre weapons are suited. Setting that aside, we come to the selection of the weapon. The weapon that was chosen was not an Australian design. The Australian designs that were submitted to the selection committee of the Department of Defence were not accepted. I think it is absolutely unconscionable that a simple weapon like a rifle, the basic infantry weapon, cannot be developed in Australia. If we cannot build our own small arms we should get right out of defence production and trying to support our own forces. It is an elementary thing. It is something we could do 50 years ago or earlier. The reason it was not accepted was purely that the Services or the Department of Defence wanted to buy overseas. I think that is a criminal mistake. We are talking about an initial order of about $180 to $200m, and over the years it will cost four or five times that amount. It is something we can do and it is something we should have done. There is no hurry for weapons. If we had an emergency we can buy weapons anywhere in the world to fill this role.

In regard to the weapon itself, not only did the Department not buy an Australian-made weapon, it bought a weapon which is not much good. I think the best weapon in that field is the Israeli Galil, but it was not considered as a runner because the Israelis put too many conditions on it. Had the Defence Department gone back to the Israelis I think they would have relaxed a bit. Let us look at the AUG Steyr we bought. It is a very good looking weapon, a real space-age weapon, but it is not good to use. I had the opportunity to fire the weapon last week, with some members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. The weapon simply has no balance. It is a weapon that will be used for instinctive shooting, for snap shooting in close patrolling. With a weapon that has no balance, you cannot get anywhere. More importantly, it turns out that this weapon has a major technical problem. The propellant charge has to be modified considerably so that the automatic feed mechanism will work.

Why are we spending $180m on a contract for something we must fix to start with? We are going down the path of HMAS Success, HMAS Tobruk, the patrol boats and the submarine program, buying something we know is not adequate and in which we must invest money to make it work. We will get something that works in a compromised way when it is finished. That is what this report is all about. I support it wholeheartedly. As I said before, there are some details with which I differ, but it has done a very important service to the Australian community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

He, in common with other observers who visited the station recently, was aghast at Casey's rubbish tip, which he says is the worst he has seen at any station in nine visits to Antarctica.
The tip is a shameful 2,000 square metres in area and up to two metres deep-shameful because official Australian policy is to aim for `zero impact' on the pristine Antarctic environment.

Station rubbish is collected in an open trailer and dumped there twice daily, irrespective of wind force and with no separation of non-combustible, toxic and hazardous materials. It is doused with petrol and ignited.
The article goes on and on. I think it is time the Antarctic Division lived up to the terms of the Antarctic Treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Send a ship down and bring it back.

—They did send a ship down there. The whole shipping program for this summer needs to be looked at in detail. We have endangered the lives of people in the Antarctic. There have been some breakdowns in equipment, but I think there have also been breakdowns in the management of the Antarctic program for this summer. The Antarctic Division would do well to take a hard look at its procedures before it risks any more lives.
—Tell us how they have broken down.
—The ships have broken down due to mechanical difficulties.
—No, the organisation.
—The organisation broke down because of lack of good planning. Page 29 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: A difficulty encountered by the Committee in its consideration of these matters is the lack of a clear policy statement by successive governments on Australia's purpose in Antarctica. The Committee believes there is an urgent need for Australia to re-examine the purpose and objectives of its presence in Antarctica.

That is exactly what the newspaper article was referring to. Are we there for science? Are we there to ensure our slice of the mineral pie? Are we there to protect the environment? It looks as though Australia is really more interested in making sure that when the goodies are handed out it is not left behind the door.
Australia is remiss in a number of areas in terms of its treaty obligations and its ratification of treaties. Page 45 of the report states:

A number of countries have announced their intentions of harvesting the crabeater seal but none has commenced. Recognising the vulnerability of seals for commercial exploitation, the Antarctic Treaty parties negotiated the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals.
This Convention was signed by Australia in 1972 and came into effect in 1978 but Australia has yet to ratify it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—This is to protect the crabeater seal. It has not been ratified. Australia could do this quite easily, but it has not taken action in this area. The Committee actually recommends that Australia ratify the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals without delay.
—That one was ratified by the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) legislation at the end of last year.

—I can only go on what the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources states. Another interesting point is made under the heading `Status as non-militarised and nuclear-free zone' on page 64 of the Committee's report. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Antarctica's status as a non-militarised and nuclear-free zone derives from the Antarctic Treaty which inter alia prohibits all measures of a military nature, such as the establishment of military bases and holding military manoeuvres; and bans nuclear explosions and the disposal of nuclear waste.
Interestingly enough, I have a letter to the editor of the Pacific Defence Reporter headed `Warm message from chill Antarctic'. The letter states:

Greetings from the South Pole. Since you and your organization are enthusiastic supporters of the Navy, I am sending you this letter from Antarctica to remind you, firstly, that 1986 is your Navy's 75th anniversary year and, secondly, of the distant and sometimes remote places in which your Navy is often found in its service to Australia.

This is signed by Rear-Admiral N. Ralph, Deputy Chief of Naval Staff, a military person at the South Pole. One wonders, since Antarctica does have a status as a non-militarised zone, what this naval officer was doing at the South Pole. If any honourable senators here can answer that question, I would be glad for them to do so.

Let us talk about wilderness. I would like to talk about the Tasmanian wilderness, but I will confine my remarks to the wilderness of the Australian Antarctic Territory and Antarctica in general. It is the last great wilderness area. Except where the bases have despoiled the environment with trash, runways and construction, Antarctica remains a wilderness. It is a prime wilderness area and deserves protection as such. One of the dangers which may arise as a result of Australia's actions is the proposed air transport system. The Committee mentions on page 78 of the report that a number of people who testified before the Committee were concerned about the possible environmental impact of an air transport system, particularly an airfield in the Vestfold Hills near Davis. Dr Johnstone, who testified before the Committee, believes that the Vestfold Hills, which he described as `the finest example in all Antarctica of a coastal oasis', would be drastically modified by the construction of the Davis airfield. Mr Harry Burton, an excellent gentleman from whom I once bought a motorcycle, stated that he was particularly concerned that airport site investigations have been taking place at Davis without any environmental protection measures having been established. He is an experienced Antarctic hand and has great concern about the status of the area in terms of its potential as an air base.

Many environmental groups appeared before the Committee and all expressed their concern that the Antarctic be preserved for future generations. However, the Government completely fails to recognise their concern. In fact, it fails to have any particular concern for the environment itself, as shown by the environmental conditions around the bases and also by its lack of any action to back expeditions such as the Greenpeace expedition. It is interesting to note that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) scathed the Greenpeace people for going to Antarctica, saying that they would get into trouble; but they went down and came out with no trouble at all while the Antarctic Division ships themselves had a lot of trouble.
The final recommendation of the Committee is as follows:

. . . That Australia propose to the Antarctic Treaty nations that a Conservation Convention for Antarctica be adopted which would strengthen existing environmental measures but permit resource exploitation under stringent environmental controls.

I feel that that is fine but that the section which says `but permit resource exploitation under stringent environmental controls' should be struck out. We should simply adopt a policy which will save the Antarctic continent, without exploitation of any kind, for all future generations to enjoy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources recommends a re-examination of Australia's policy towards Antarctica. It endorses the current policy of maintaining Australia's claim to sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory, which represents 60 per cent of the Antarctic land mass by area or 42 per cent of the region by angle. It endorses Australia's continued support of the Antarctic Treaty, which has maintained stability and peace in the region for 25 years. It also endorses Australia's scientific endeavour in the Antarctic and its primary importance to decision making on Antarctic policy. It recommends that Australia reconsider its Antarctic policy with respect to its desire to recoup the costs of its Antarctic program by exploiting the living and non-living resources of the Antarctic.

SPEECH.PARA: Science and conservation go hand in hand. The Antarctic environment is immensely fragile. There is no natural way in which rubbish can decay, oil spills can be absorbed or dust can be reincorporated in the earth. Senator Sanders has dealt very adequately with this aspect of our presence in Antarctica. I am pleased to see that the Antarctic Division of the Department of Science is talking about a clean-up program over five years in which it is going to cart rubbish back from Antarctica. Mining in the Antarctic would cause irreversible damage and a valuable natural wilderness and scientific laboratory which is extremely important to our long term survival on earth could be destroyed.

Because of the difficult environment for man, scientific research proceeds very slowly in Antarctica. Data on both living and non-living resources is being obtained only slowly, and at a very high cost both to the individual scientists themselves and to the nations sponsoring them. It is essential, however, that adequate research be done on the natural resources in this area so that we can understand what the effects of over- exploitation can be on the continent. Currently, overexploitation is happening without research being carried out.

Fishing has been practised in Antarctica for many years. The resulting disasters so far include near-extermination of several whale species, the fishing out of whole areas of fin fish around South Georgia Island and a devastating effect on the krill population of this area which is making it very difficult for the whale population to re-grow.

The Russians continue to fish for fin fish in the Antarctic but refuse to provide data on their catch. It is important that enough pressure be put on the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to record its fish catches so that a watch can be kept on possible further depletion of this particular resource which may be extremely important to the future of mankind.

Krill-those tiny prawn-like creatures which appear to be the primary food source of all the larger animals and birds in this area-are being harvested by Japan and the USSR. No statistics are being kept on this. Already evidence is mounting that this, as yet, `experimental' harvesting of krill may be seriously depleting the area. We do not know anything at all about the life cycle of krill that can tell us exactly--

TALK.START.PARA: —What absolute nonsense.

—Maybe the honourable senator does know, but I would be quite surprised. If he does I hope that he will be contributing to the debate. The length of its life cycle has definitely been underestimated and that is why the populations are being depleted. The basic message that I am trying to get across is that more research is needed.

SPEECH.PARA: Research is also proceeding into the mineral resources of the Antarctic. Mining could cause irreparable damage to some areas of the Antarctic. We have to try to get adequate funds for research. In Australia most of our funds are being spent on getting an infrastructure-on building up bases which are comfortable for scientists to live in rather than on research. Less than 20 per cent of the money that is being spent in Antarctica is being spent on research per se. The rest is spent just on providing infrastructure.

Australian scientists who have been carrying out research in the Antarctic for years are withdrawing from their programs. This year, for the first time, the Mawson Institute based in Adelaide has no researchers in the Antarctic and funding for this Institute of world renown is so inadequate that the University of Adelaide is considering closing it down when Dr Jacka, the current Director, retires in several years time. Research in the Antarctic requires such special support that the level of funding must be increased. We must look at the priorities and make certain that the spending is reasonable. The support problems in the area are problems of transport, accommodation and planning, and Senator Sanders has told us something about the breakdown in planning.

TALK.START.PARA: —What breakdown?

—We have sent ships out there without adequate weather information and they have got caught in the ice. Transport from Australia to the Antarctic until this year has depended on the availability of charter ships like the Nella Dan. This year it was stuck in the ice, as were a number of other ships.
—We need some airstrips down there. That is the problem.

—Coming to airstrips, I point out that even the Antarctic Division does not believe that, and I have talked to them recently. In fact the alternative of air transport to Antarctic bases has been investigated by the Antarctic Division, an environmental impact study was started, but it has been dropped because a cost-benefit study found that the cost and the times to transport people and goods by air are non-viable. The reason is the weather at the bases: The time required for getting air transport into the bases is longer than the time required for actually getting the ships in because there are so many days of the week in which it is impossible to fly safely. The Antarctic Division has assured me that no airstrips are planned to be built in the Antarctic by Australia in the foreseeable future. That decision has been taken as the result of a proper cost benefit study.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Australians will make available to the French their cost-benefit studies so that the airstrip at Dumont d'Urville, which is causing immeasurable ecological damage to that area, will actually be stopped. The French have to realise that the cost of their airstrip is just not worth it, especially if the Australians offered some other local support to them in return for their not continuing with it.

Rebuilding of the three Australian bases is proceeding as fast as delays in transport and the short Antarctic summer permit. Funds for the Antarctic program apparently have increased considerably over the last couple of years, but most of this increase has been put into the rebuilding program. Because of the limited transport available, we are really wasting a lot of resources and it may well be worth accelerating the program in order that we can actually get on with some of the real research.

The Division is also spending $1m per base on rubbish compactors, which I am sure Senator Sanders will be interested in, and they plan to use earth moving gear to take out the existing rubbish, the extent of which has been described by Senator Sanders. The problems of recovering garbage are very important. Australia has decided to containerise all the materials being sent to Antarctica so that the containers can be used for returning the rubbish. I commend the Division for that. I think that is an extremely important aspect of its work.

We have to think about a maintainable ecosystem. Fuel requirements are currently planned to be minimised by wind energy research, which fits in with our Party's policy. A housing system is being developed with a view to its export potential for people at other bases in the area. As the Democrats spokesman on trade, I commend this.

I believe that we have to think about Antarctica, which is our last great wilderness, and do our best to make certain that Australian and other people in the Antarctic do not do irreparable damage to the area. It is extremely important that we continue to support the Antarctic Treaty, which has made the most important contribution to peace in the world because Antarctica is a zone of peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, before I commence my remarks may I take this opportunity, as this is the first occasion I have been on my feet since you have been back in the chair, to say what a pleasure it is to see you back in that place.
—Thank you.

—Secondly, I apologise to Senator Brownhill and my other colleagues who want to get on to the debate about dolphins and cetacea in captivity, but I am prompted to intervene in this debate because it really does get to the stage when one gets absolutely fed up with spokesmen for the Australian Democrats ranting on about such areas as the environment and Antarctic policy without having the faintest idea what they are talking about. Let me give just two examples. Senator Sanders waved his arms about the failure to ratify the Convention for the Protection of Antarctic Seals. I quote from Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1985, Act No. 65 of 1985, under the heading on page 12 of `Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980':

SPEECH.PARA: Preamble-
Add at the end the following paragraphs:
``AND WHEREAS Australia is a Party to the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals:
``AND WHEREAS it is desirable to make provision for giving effect to that Convention:''.

It goes on to change the definition of `animal', to change the definition of `native mammal', to change the definition of `property' and to insert a whole series of new parts into the law. Back in May and June of 1985 we dealt with Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) which in fact ratified the treaty which Senator Sanders claimed had not been ratified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take it up with the Committee. In December 1985 the Committee said that it had not been passed yet.

—I expect the honourable senator to have the wit and intelligence to do his own research on areas in which he claims to be a spokesman for his Party. As far as the second point is concerned, Senator Vigor complains here about the lack of research into and lack of knowledge of the lifecycle of the Antarctic krill. As my colleague Senator Cooney would know, the amount of research done in Australia into the lifestyle of euphasia superba, as the beast is properly known, is quite extensive. Australian scientists throughout the Antarctic Division, throughout the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and throughout the Australian National and James Cook Universities have studied euphasia superba at some considerable length and the details of the lifecycle of Antarctic krill are well known, as indeed are the controversies of the fishing arrangements and the particular problems which have arisen from the level of krill catches, particularly those undertaken by the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, Senator Vigor indicated a concern about the mining regime. Had he bothered to study the papers prepared by Mr Beeby, the New Zealand representative who chairs the mining sub-committee which deals with these matters in the Antarctic, he would have known that Australian governments, both this Government and its predecessor, have taken an extremely constructive approach to the development of the required pre-conditional environmental safeguards to be put in place before any minerals regime is established in the Antarctic. Back in May 1981, as I recall, Senator Jessop and I were both delegates on behalf of this Parliament to a meeting of the consultative parties to the Treaty which took place here in Canberra to deal with the conservation of the living marine resources of the Antarctic, and the extent to which the Government, of which we were then members, had established a very lengthy interest in the Antarctic I think needs to be recorded. Senator Vigor complains here that allegedly the Antarctic Division is responsible for the fact that the Nella Dan got trapped in an ice-floe. While one expects Commonwealth departments to have some degree of prescience in these matters, it comes as fairly strange to find that a government department is criticised because a ship a couple of thousand kilometres away in the Antarctic gets trapped in an ice-floe.

If one of the United States or Soviet Union's nuclear-powered ice breakers is called upon to rescue an Australian vessel and perhaps to refuel or supply in an Australian port prior to going to the Antarctic to assist in one of these matters, it will be very interesting to see whether the Australian Democrats go through their schizophrenic problem of deciding whether they would rather have the ice broken or the nuclear-powered ship excluded from Australian waters. Presumably, given the way in which they have carried on about these things, they would rather have the Australian vessel trapped in the ice than use the nuclear-powered icebreaker to get it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it funny? World War III could start and you would laugh about it. You would make a joke about it.

—The only chance of World War III starting would be if people were dumb enough to adopt the policy positions of the Australian Democrats. The next point to which I draw attention is the extent to which in essence Senator Vigor has failed properly to convey the representations which have been made by the Australian Government and the Antarctic Division in particular towards the French development of the airstrip at Dumont d'Urville. I think anybody who has paid attention to the representations which have been made as far as the French Government is concerned about its plans at Dumont d'Urville will know that the criticism made by Senator Vigor in that regard was quite unjustified.

SPEECH.PARA: As somebody who did not want particularly to intervene in this debate, I do, however, believe that it was necessary, quite simply because, if the Australian Democrats are going to deal with a matter as important and as significant as Australia's policy in the Antarctic and are going to criticise both previous governments and the current Government over matters dealing with the Antarctic Treaty and Antarctic policy, they ought at least to do the Senate the courtesy of relying on the facts rather than relying on their imaginations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, may I also say how pleased I am to see you back in the chair. I look forward to working with you for many years. I wish to make a remark or two on the report entitled `The natural resources of the Australian Antarctic Treaty'. I have not had a chance to read it thoroughly, but I look forward to reading it in detail because I have been to the Antarctic and I have visited the South Pole. I have visited several research stations at Casey, the Scott and McMurdo bases and the South Pole itself. I was impressed with the amount of work the scientists were doing at that time in atmospheric physics, in their study of the ozone layer and the possible effect of fluorocarbons on that layer. Cosmic physics was a very important aspect of their studies. Ice core studies were being carried out using carbon dating methods to study the ice core so that scientists can trace the history of the area back to the Industrial Revolution and study the effects of world pollution. Biological studies are being carried out on the food chain, with particular emphasis on krill and its importance to the larger animals there.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to hear Senator Vigor say that he was not in favour of using aircraft to convey scientists to the South Pole. I travelled on a Hercules which was equipped with skis. It is fairly expensive to equip a Hercules with skis. I think it costs something of the order of $2m to $3m. A quite sophisticated hydraulic mechanism needs to be applied. So it is an expensive operation. Having regard to the importance of scientific research in that area and the need to get more scientists down there and the fact, as Senator Vigor pointed out, that the Nella Dan occasionally runs into ice flows that prevent its passage to the Antarctic, it seems to me to be quite sensible that those in the Antarctic Division of the Department of Science should examine further the possibility of using Hercules aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have, and they have rejected the idea. That is where I got my information from.
—They should re-examine it, I think, because the Americans--
—They just have.
—What conclusion have they come to?
—That it is not viable.
—They have changed their minds. It seems to me to be very important to get quicker access to the South Pole. I imagine that the Antarctic Division ought to have another look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Dolphins and Whales in Captivity

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 November 1985, on motion by Senator Georges:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tabling of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare report on the keeping of cetacea in captivity marks a watershed for animal welfare in Australia. My decision, therefore, to oppose the Committee and issue a dissenting report was not taken lightly. Having taken that decision, I believe that I have been proven right by the only people who are qualified to comment. I refer to those scientists, marine park operators, zoologists and marine biologists who work in the field of cetacea.

SPEECH.PARA: I have received telegrams, telexes and letters from organisations and individuals throughout the United States of America, Canada, Europe, the United Kingdom and New Zealand as well as from a variety of academics, researchers and scientists in Australian universities. The letters from organisations in the United States represent hundreds of different groups and involve millions of people. I have received letters from groups such as the American Association of Zoological Parks and Aquariums, the International Union of Directors of Zoological Gardens, representing 38 countries, and the Society of Mammalogists and from universities around the world. Every letter was in support of my arguments. Each one has questioned the lack of scientific data, professional examination and evidence and the validity of conclusions. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two of these letters as evidence of the strong feelings of the scientific and zoological community.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
THE NATIONAL FEDERATION OF ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS OF GREAT BRITAIN AND IRELAND
Chairman The Earl of Cranbrook ma, Phd
Zoological Gardens
Regent's Park, London NW1 4RY
3 March 1986

Dear Prime Minister
The National Federation of Zoological Gardens of Great Britain and Ireland is the only organisation to represent zoological gardens and aquaria in Great Britain and Ireland.

We have recently been informed that the Government of Victoria and the Central Senate of Australia are contemplating legislation to prevent the further development of marine parks and the phasing out of existing ones. Our attention has been drawn to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare as it applies to Dolphins and Whales in Captivity.

We have now had the opportunity to read the extremely comprehensive report and as a result feel that the National Federation is in a position to respond in support of other world zoo bodies, who have expressed concern that unsatisfactory legislation may be enacted as a result of the Select Committee's recommendations.
The Federation's opinion would be that the scientific evidence provided thus far, is not conclusive enough to warrant all the recommendations of the Select Committee.

We believe that it was absolutely correct that such a study be carried out, and indeed in the United Kingdom at the present time, Dr Margaret Klinowska is undertaking a similar study, which has been commissioned by the Department of the Environment.

There is no doubt that standards of husbandry need to be set and the scientific and important educational advantages of keeping cetacea in captivity should be given far greater emphasis by any dolphinaria that currently may be failing to do so.

The National Federation hopes that the Senate will seek through legislation to improve the keeping of cetacea in captivity by ensuring that the standards of good husbandry which have already been achieved in some Australian collections, be implemented rather than closing down all dolphinaria because some collections are unsatisfactory. In the United Kingdom, the Zoo Licensing Act 1981 has been most effective in imposing standards. We cannot accept the conclusion of the Committee that the benefits of oceanaria are no longer sufficient to justify the adverse affects of capture for captivity. The burden of scientific proof within the report does not appear to have been met.

The Committee itself seems slightly ambivalent over this matter as one of its recommendations is that the keeping of cetacea should eventually be phased out unless further research justifies their continuance. The Federation agrees with many of the recommendations relating to husbandry, display, education, research and licensing and agrees with the dissenting recommendations of Senator D Brownhill as set out in the report.

Finally, we would wish to reiterate the belief that it is important that any decision relating to marine mammals in captivity, particularly those which are able to make an important educational and scientific contribution, should only be made on the basis of sound scientific evidence.

Rodney Able, Marine World, Victoria
AAZPA
THE UNIVERSITY OF NEWCASTLE
NEW SOUTH WALES, 2308
Department of Biological Sciences
Telephone 68 0401
7 February 1986
Senator D. Brownhill,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Brownhill,

I would urge you to carefully consider the Report on Dolphins and Whales in captivity of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. If the report is accepted in its present form not only could the study of these marine mammals be seriously curtailed but it would, in my view, set a very negative principle for future animal welfare legislation affecting scientific research.

It is well accepted by the scientific community that the welfare of research animals is an important ethical consideration. Institutions have responded to recent criticism by establishing codes of practice and committees to oversee that they are applied. In this respect then, I applaud those recommendations of the Committee's report which will bring the management of animals in marine parks under such a code and appropriate supervision.

Unfortunately it appears that the Committee has taken the view that even such ethical animal care is objectionable and should eventually be banned. This is of course simply the Animal Liberation Movement view and in this case it appears to be based largely on the supposed high intelligence of whales. Although this is a commonly presented view in television nature programs it has little support from those who actually study brain function and animal intelligence.

That our society needs to develop an ethical system for its treatment and use of all living things is virtually a tenet of modern biology, but I am concerned that this ethic has a rational base and is not simply an emotional response supported by pseudo science or conjecture. If we take this route we fall into the trap of creating an ``unethical'' animal welfare system concerned only with the animals we find attractive, or are familiar with, and those that threaten or are ugly are overlooked.

The living resources of our country need protection from exploitation and abuse, but to do this will require the knowledge of Australian animals and their environment which is the aim of scientific research. Curtailment of research will ultimately endanger native animals and threaten their welfare.
Yours sincerely,
John C. Rodger, Ph.D.
Lecturer

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In summary, my objections relate to three conclusions in the report; namely, recommendations 8.8, 8.9 and 8.10. My objections are based on two arguments-firstly, the emotional approach which has coloured the issue and, secondly, the lack of scientific evidence. On the question of emotive language, I cite three examples. The report contains such comments as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a new ethic was emerging . . . aimed at shifting the perspective . . . to recognise the moral claims of other species . . .
This may be found on page 29. Page 32 contains the following statement:
. . . many consider that display of cetacea in a captive setting reinforces the notion that humans are entitled to dominate and exploit animals. . . .
Page 85 contains the following statement:
. . . oceanaria exploits cetacea primarily for profit and . . . this is morally indefensible . . .

I do not believe that type of emotive phasing belongs in a serious Senate document. There is an assumption contained in those statements and throughout the report that somehow it is morally wrong for man to use animals in any way other than in a social, equal relationship. That is absurd. Where does that leave any animal enterprise? Where does that place the livestock industries in Australia or indeed the companion animal industry? There are many people in the animal liberation movement who have philosophies similar to those expressed in the quotes I have just read from the report. However, I do not believe that a Senate committee report should give them further credence. The second ground on which I object is the lack of scientific evidence to support many of the Committee's recommendations. Recommendation 8.7 argues:
. . . the committee is of the opinion that evidence points to the probability that cetacea are highly intelligent animals with complex social behaviour.

The truth is that there is not sufficient evidence to lead the Committee to that conclusion. The argument of dolphin intelligence and the secondary one, linking it with complex social behaviour, has been refuted by authorities around the world. In Australia both Dr Michael Bryden, from the University of Queensland, and Dr G. Phelps, from Atlantis, Western Australia, have written that there is no relationship between complex social behaviour and intelligence. Their argument is supported by many people working with dolphins and by researchers in universities around the world. Dr Phelps claims that at best scientific evidence and research would indicate that dolphins are on a par with dogs, pigs, seals, and bears. He and Bryden have both written that complex social behaviour is not regarded as a sign of intelligence. Bees and ants have complex social behaviour but they are not noted for their intellect.

The second argument used by the Committee to support its claim for intellectual capacity is brain size. The classic rebuttal of that argument is the comparison between the male and female human brains. The male human brain is larger but it was long ago established that it is not superior to the female's. A wide variety of marine biologists, researchers, scientists and academics have objected to the Committee's conclusions. They claim that fundamental misconceptions have led to illogical and unsupportable recommendations. The scientific community is also concerned at the acceptance of scientific evidence from non-scientists. It argues that much misinformation has been reported from people who are discredited among authoritative bodies. An example of this is the evidence that was taken on loss of acoustic ability among captive cetacea. A study of papers on the subject indicates that there is no evidence to suggest that this is true. In Australia work has been conducted at Atlantis, Western Australia, over five years on this subject with no recorded loss being established. Mortality rates and longevity among captive cetacea have also been misreported by the opponents of cetecea in captivity. Claims of high death rates, quoted in the report, are outdated and irrelevant. Modern oceanaria have a high success rate in husbandry of their animals. Again, Atlantis is a leader. In more than five years of operation there have been no deaths. On the other hand, successful breeding in captivity is increasing with calves being born at Marine Land, South Australia, at the Porpoise Pool, Coffs Harbour, and at Warragamba, New South Wales.

Claims have been made that little research is done with cetacea in captivity. Again this is wrong. Only recently a young student, Michael Hill, was a finalist in the BHP National Science Prize. His paper examined the bioacoustics of bottlenose dolphins, based on work he had done with dolphins in captivity in Western Australia. Other work has recently been completed by an American post-graduate student at Atlantis on feeding habits and aging patterns. He was unable to finalise his report without using captive cetacea.

Recently the Committee Chairman, Senator Georges, was quoted on television as saying that little work has been done on the accidental trapping of dolphins in gill nets. The truth is that substantial work has been done on this subject and is continuing. This work would have been impossible without the availability of captive dolphins. More than 3,000 dolphins are trapped each year in gill nets. Only 50 dolphins are kept in oceanaria. Yet it is these captive dolphins that have attracted the attention of the animal liberationists while thousands of others die accidentally each year as a result of fishing operations. The argument is not in perspective.

Perhaps the most obnoxious section of this report lies in the recommendation concerning the future of oceanaria in Australia. Supporters of the report argue that existing oceanaria should be allowed to continue. However, the phrase `for the time being' is included. That statement is economically irresponsible, mischievous and confusing. The innuendo contained in that phrase threatens the economic stability of every oceanarium in Australia. Whether the animal welfare supporter wishes to acknowledge the fact or not, in all animal operations there is an economic consideration. That applies equally to the RSPCA's program for rescuing stray dogs and to dolphins in captivity.
