TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is debating the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. By agreement we are debating each Article separately under clause 8. The Article before the Committee is Article 2, to which Senator Vigor has moved an amendment. The question is: That the words proposed to be left out by Senator Vigor's amendment be left out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was indicating before lunch, the Government's response to Article 2 of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is first of all to make the point that it is there for a purpose. That purpose is to indicate clearly that the mere existence of the rights set out in the Bill of Rights does not in any way amount to a diminution of the status of any other rights that may happen to exist independently-whether those other rights exist as a matter of strict law in the form of statutory rights or common law rights or whether, rather, they exist by way of some other claim of right which may not be formally recognised as a matter of law but which, as Senator Vigor points out, might be acknowledged in some international treaty to which Australia is a party and in relation to which obligations have been accepted but where those obligations have not been translated through into domestic law.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, what Article 2 says quite clearly and unequivocally in its present form, and it may be justified in being extended to some small extent to make it clear that the other rights that are not being affected by this Bill of Rights are treaty rights and things of that kind which are not, strictly speaking, part of the law, is that the Bill of Rights is not an exhaustive account of those rights which are deserving of recognition and protection. The reason Article 2 is there really is to counter squarely what has been one of the most common and unjustified attacks on the Bill of Rights, namely, that it is some sort of exhaustive account and that, rather than enhancing the condition of human rights in this country, the Bill of Rights would, as a result, in fact diminish them. The argument we have heard all too often that to define rights is somehow to restrict them is and always has been nonsense, but the language of Article 2 puts that claim completely beyond dispute. Just to put it clearly on the record, Article 2 states:

A right or freedom existing under, or recognised by, any other law shall not be taken to have been diminished or derogated from by reason only that the right or freedom is not set out in this Bill of Rights.

So it is acknowledged, as I began before lunch by saying, that there are plenty of other rights, properly so called, lying around, certainly recognised in law, which it is not the purpose of this Bill of Rights to address. Equally it is not the purpose of this Bill of Rights in any way to restrict the enjoyment of such other rights as might exist. This is very relevant, of course, to the arguments we will no doubt have shortly about the absence of protection in this Bill of Rights of the right to property or certain aspects of the right to education and perhaps a number of other rights that might be claimed to social security and things of that kind. The mere fact that those kinds of rights, for one reason or another, are not set out in this International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and not adopted in this Bill of Rights is not to be taken as signifying any lack of respect or any lack of protection for them. It is just that that respect is manifested and that protection is given in other ways than under this particular document.

If one understands what Article 2 is all about, why it is there and how it fits into the scheme of things, the remaining question becomes one of the drafting of Article 2. Here Senator Vigor has expressed all sorts of concerns about that and has urged an alternative formulation, which he says is aimed at the same general conceptual approach but does the job better. I agree that his formulation is in some ways more succinct and punchy, but one of the difficulties about it is that it may in fact have the ultimate result of diminishing the enjoyment of certain rights which deserve to be fully and thoroughly protected. Let me explain how that might work. Senator Vigor's proposition makes it absolutely clear that any other right which may exist around the place continues to exist and be enjoyed irrespective of whether the subject matter of that right is addressed in this Bill of Rights. Rather than being confined, as the present draft of Article 2 is, to rights which are not addressed in this Bill of Rights, Senator Vigor's amendment protects the existence not only of rights which are not addressed in the Bill of Rights but also of rights which are addressed in the Bill of Rights. If we have a right which is not especially well protected under the existing law but is much better protected under the Bill of Rights, and yet the existing right goes on being protected, and the correlative duty associated with that existing right goes on being accepted, then we can have a situation where someone who is making a claim of right under the Bill of Rights will be met with the argument that that right is satisfied by the right which exists in a lesser form in the existing law.

That is all very abstract. Let me give a concrete example of what it is all about. Take for example the Judges Rules, so called, at common law for the protection of suspects in criminal cases. Those Judges Rules, as is notorious, go some of the way towards protecting the suspect, but certainly not the distance that is covered in articles 19, 21, 22, 23 and so on of this Bill. I will not stop to track through the detail of that. I think it would be acknowledged that the particular rights in the Bill of Rights here, which are quite specific in this area, go further than, and are more substantial than, the Judges Rules rights. If we have a criminal suspect who is arguing that his rights have not been fully protected and he is met with the argument `Your rights under the Judges Rules have been protected' under Senator Vigor's amendment he is met with the difficulty, coming along to a court reviewing his application for protection, that the court would not be able to say that the Judges Rules have been displaced by the enhanced statement of rights in the Bill of Rights itself. Yet again, as so often in this debate, it is a technical point I am making. I am not denying in any way the endeavour lying behind Senator Vigor's amendment, but the very way in which it is written will have an effect that his draftsman has not anticipated and which would be most unfortunate.

Let it be acknowledged that in his contribution to the debate and in subsequent discussion Senator Vigor has made it clear that his primary concern is to ensure that the other rights which go on being recognised are not just rights which are formally recognised as a matter of law, which is the way the Government's Article 2 is drafted at the moment. He is also concerned to ensure, as after all is Article 5.2 of the International Covenant on which all this is based, that other less well entrenched rights, less well protected rights, nonetheless are still recognised. He is talking about customary rights, which are not, under our system, recognised as a matter of law. He is talking about conventions which are not part of our domestic law but which do have a status. He is talking about international conventions, as well as other kinds, which create obligations internationally for us and which certainly create claims of right but which have not yet been translated and which it may be are inappropriate to be translated into domestic law. Some of the rights to education and so on under the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights would satisfy that description. What he is asking is whether Article 2 should not be extended in such a way that it acknowledges the existence of those other categories of rights. If Senator Vigor wants to withdraw his previous amendment and cast an amendment in those terms, about which there has been some discussion, I do not think the Government would have any difficulty in agreeing with him. Perhaps that would be a satisfactory solution to this particular issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise because I understood the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) to say that it is nonsense to say that to define rights is to limit or restrict them. That astonishes me. I would not know how many times I have read judicial and legal statements on exactly this matter. One has only to think about it to realise that if there is nonsense it lies in what the Minister has said. A right is a community understanding in itself, and within a community understanding and within the abstract concept of that community understanding the community in its tolerance allows elastic limits; it allows a tolerance of movements within rights. As soon as one goes to a court and tests the rights, the firm walls of imprisonment of those rights are established. I cannot do more than stress that what we are talking about are not the things that give us freedom if they are written in words for the law to interpret. Rights and freedoms are what a community, by consensus, agrees exist at that time, and they are not imprisoned in any way.

SPEECH.PARA: I think somebody better than I once said: `We vivisect the nightingale to probe the secret of its voice'. It is a beautiful concept which reveals in itself that when one seeks that mystique of the nightingale's song by looking with a scalpel one in fact takes away the mystique, takes away the beauty, and one is left with something that is not reality. The reality of rights are the abstractions, the values that the community places on those rights. The reality of rights is not their enforcement by law but the tolerance of the elbowroom of the community as they move through. I repeat, if we apply the test here of vivisecting the nightingale in this case those abstract freedoms to probe the secret of its voice will find what the vivisectionist does; that the mystique, the whole of the value has gone, that the laboratory itself, whether it is a legal laboratory or a scientific laboratory, has not the magic that the community and the consensus bring towards it. So I reject that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment, as has already been indicated by Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Harradine, will not alter the situation at all unless Senator Evans agrees that the customs and conventions are as I see them. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — It appears, with the utmost respect, that Senator Walters has once again got the bull by the wrong appendage. We are talking about Article 2 of the Bill of Rights. I make it clear for this purpose that the Bill of Rights is the series of articles set out in clause 8. SPEECH.PARA: One of the interesting things that might give her some comfort is that a corollary of what I am saying is that if clause 29 (2) governing certain of the procedures of the Human Rights Commission investigating these matters is in fact offensive to one or other of the rights that are set out in the actual articles of the Bill of Rights we could have the situation where that procedure could be challenged under one of the heads of clause 8, one of those articles. TALK.START.PARA: —Why could it not be challenged?

—The honour- able senator's imagination is pretty fertile in these areas and maybe she can find a way. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some general comments on Article 2 and the debate which has taken place on it. I think Senator Gareth Evans, on behalf of the Government, has been backed into a rather odd and confused situation in seeking to make a concession to Senator Vigor. If I look at Article 2 as a lawyer in purely legal terms, it is quite an innocuous and unnecessary Article. I can see why lawyers thought that it was a good idea to put it in. They wanted to make it perfectly clear that the Bill of Rights is allegedly guaranteeing a number of rights. We will be debating how it does that when we come to the next clause. We know that there are a whole lot of laws on the statute books created by judges under which people have got rights. Clearly we do not want to take away any of the rights that are already there. Probably most of the rights that people enjoy will not be covered by this Bill of Rights at all; they have been covered by all the laws that have been developed for hundreds of years by the courts and, particularly this century, by parliaments passing laws. The whole complex of the legal system under which we live has arisen in that way and this Bill of Rights is only a further part of that process.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at this Article as a lawyer, one would not, in any way, be disturbed about it. If we were all thinking as lawyers the legislation would have gone through without any debate. The fact of the matter is that Senator Vigor expressed concern and that his proposed amendment goes to the very heart of the process of having a Bill of Rights. I can understand and sympathise entirely with what he is concerned about. He is really concerned that we have a Bill of Rights and we have an exercise like this going on at all. Senator Vigor has stated that people are concerned that by passing this Bill of Rights we are guaranteeing-Senator Harradine has made the same point-a certain discreet group of rights as being superior to, and different from, all the other rights and privileges that we enjoy in the free society in which we live-the fairly unique situation in this country.

To meet this concern, Senator Gareth Evans has conceded to the extension of the word `law' to `conventions and customs'. Lawyers will be confronted with interpreting this. They will not understand and will say: `What is this custom, what is this convention which is different from a law? If it is not a law we do not understand it. We are there to enforce laws. What are these conventions or customs that you are talking about'? So it goes on. It is only confusing the issue even more. The fundamental point is that living in a free society we derive our freedom not from what government or parliaments conceded to us, but from the whole development of our community as a free society over hundreds of years. The notion that we have got rights only because the Government has given them to us is a legalistic approach, a lawyer's approach, to this whole issue. We have recognised that in our society we have got our rights as individuals. It is only by the imposition of laws on us that those rights are reduced or qualified in some way. This issue goes to the fundamental conception of our society and where our rights come from and how we enjoy them. Lawyers will give an answer to it in one way and they give it by way of legislation.

Senator Vigor is concerned about this deeper and more fundamental question. He is rightly expressing that concern because so many other people have a concern about the very basic concept of a Bill of Rights. I think if one has that concern the proper thing to do-Senator Harradine has already mentioned this-is to vote against the whole concept of a Bill of Rights, because it is totally at variance with the nature of our society. We do not need Parliament saying we have got a whole lot of rights; we just do not need that at all-we have got them, we have enjoyed them and we have fought for them. Members of parliaments have got a basic obligation to the society we represent to preserve the fundamental freedoms which we have enjoyed as they have developed through the whole history of our society. It is not for a government or a parliament to pat people on the head and say: `You have got these rights. We are singling them out as the rights that you have'. Of course, Article 2 concedes clearly that we have other rights. We have all those other rights. We have them not only under laws that have been passed but under the guarantees of our free society. Religious people, philosophers and so on have used various expressions to describe the concepts of natural rights. I do not want to start debating them, but the nature of the rights of human beings has been a well known concept of philosophers and other thinkers for centuries. It is very difficult to explain them in words. The fact is that we know them when we see them, when we enjoy them, and particularly when they are being taken away from us. Last night the Committee very wisely expanded the interpretation and the application of this legislation so that it would apply not only to the acts and practices of governments but also to other large groups in the community that can affect individuals' rights, namely, corporations and trade unions. That was a step in the right direction.

I do not believe that we can do anything about this particular Article. I do not think any amendments would make an improvement one way or the other because the Article expresses a fundamentally wrong approach to the question of preserving rights. The entire Bill of Rights is proceeding along those lines. I am quite relaxed, one way or the other, as to what wording is included in Article 2. I do not think it would make any difference whether it was included at all, whether it was included in the form the Government proposes, or whether it was in the form that is now proposed by the amendment we are considering. What Senator Vigor was really worried about was expressed in his original amendment. Unfortunately, that amendment does not have any meaning with regard to the enforcement of the clause by courts. They are concerned only with the rights that are formalised in laws passed by the Parliament or judgments of courts, whereas the fundamentals of our rights are engraved in the hearts and minds of people who have made a free society and who live in and will defend a free society. That is where our great strength comes from. That is where the real guarantee of the rights of our community comes from.

I think this whole exercise, which is exemplified by article 2 and the various suggestions of what words may be used, is quite beside the point. I emphasise that the nature of this concern Senator Vigor has expressed, and the concern so many other people have expressed, means that the whole exercise of having a Bill of Rights is totally false, misleading, and contrary to the way in which we have achieved rights in our free society and the way in which we will continue to preserve those rights.

If I can, let me define, I hope, as a philosophic liberal, what I think are my freedoms. First of all, I think freedoms are responsibility. I gain freedom by exercising my responsibility to give freedom to others and the right to be different. The right to be different is fundamental. We turn these things into something that somebody will want to exploit. Let me stick to my moonbeams. They have substance, beauty and quality. Above everything else, they depend on the magic that freedom and rights must have. That is the magic-that a free society poses a voluntary responsibility on individuals. It is not done in an Act of law at all. This society could not work if the responsibilities of human beings were simply prescribed. It works because human beings understand their responsibilities and want to widen the freedom of others because they know that their freedoms are widened in that way. No amount of prescription of law, no amount of law saying that as a citizen one must allow the right of the other fellow to be different will bring that about. It can only be brought about in the hearts and minds of people.

Senator Evans has talked about America. I happened deliberately to have been in the United States of America for quite some months during the 1960s in order to see the evolution of the freedom of the blacks. I moved amongst them, I lived amongst them, and I sat as an observer on Lyndon Johnson's committee to look into the whole question of black rights. That did not come with the passing of the laws. It came with the emergence of the American conscience.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill of Rights was the vehicle.

—It was the American conscience which gave the theatre and the environment. I commend to Senator Evans a reading of the report of the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence, which was set up with people such as Percy and Kirkham as members. They said to the American people: `You have created this monster. You took these people 250 years ago from Africa as slaves. You brought them here. You enslaved them, you dehumanised them, you refused them the right to be humans. You refused them the right of marriage. You wanted to breed them because it was a capital asset. You denied them rights'. It was the exposure of the horror of some 250 years, the exposure of the heartache of the Civil War from 1861 to 1865, when Americans lost more people than they did in World War I and World War II together, that brought that change about. It was the recognition by the Americans that they had done wrong and that a right now had to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, no amount of passing of laws will give our Australian Aborigines a right to dignity, a right to a proper place, a right to be different in our society. I think it is utterly wrong to assume that. In fact, I was passing along a street in Atlanta or in Alabama when I saw in the middle of the city a huge area overrun with jungle. When I asked `What is that?', I was told: `That was the zoological gardens'. I asked : `Why do you put it in the past tense?' They said: `It was a zoo until they passed a law. The law said that the blacks as well as the whites should go into the zoo, so we closed the zoo'. That is the first class evidence of how the law works. When one went in the 1960s to look at the situation one realised that the American people looked to their consciences.

If I appear to have been speaking in the abstract on this matter it is because the essence of the argument is to try to understand that freedoms and rights are not things to be put in captivity at all. They are free-flying things. They are the creatures of the society that creates them. If we try to capture them we will restrict them and destroy them. I repeat: Those little moonbeams that Senator Evans had so much joy about and which he thought would be so much better put in writing are in writing in so many totalitarian countries. When one takes out the scalpel one sees that there is nothing there. Let us have them in our hearts and minds and not in some document. In any case Senator Evans's arguments fall very short because they are very selective. He wants put into writing only those rights and freedoms that he wants in writing. He leaves out all the others. He has an absolutely selective judgment when he comes to the protection of rights. I stick to the poets. I reject the plumbers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on clause 8 has been very important because it goes to the very heart of the Bill of Rights. Senator Vigor has moved an amendment which I think originally sought to give expression to a different view of the Bill of Rights Bill from that of the Government. As I have said, the Opposition is opposed to the Bill of Rights. Some of the reasons why we oppose it certainly are bound up with the concerns Senator Vigor expressed in the amendment he first proposed. The difficulty with that amendment was that it was very difficult to interpret, looking at it as a lawyer, how it would work and operate, bearing in mind that it is largely lawyers who are going to have to make it work in the future. However, Senator Vigor has withdrawn this amendment. I think he has agreed to a suggestion by Senator Gareth Evans that Article 2 should be amended so that it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A right or freedom existing under, or recognised by, any other law, convention or custom shall not be taken to have been diminished . . .

That, I think, creates considerable difficulty in interpretation if one is looking at it purely as a lawyer. Senator Vigor has indicated that what he really does not believe should be in this clause at all are the words `by reason only that the right or freedom is not set out in this Bill of Rights'. Although I did not hear him say this, I understand that he has indicated that he would be pleased to delete those words, so that what we would have would be:
A right or freedom existing under, or recognised by, any other law, shall not be taken to have been diminished or derogated from by this Bill of Rights.

I believe that is entirely consistent with the view the Opposition has been expressing in relation to this matter, and I would certainly be prepared to support Senator Vigor's amendment if he were so disposed. Indeed, if he is not, I would be prepared to move that those words be deleted. If Senator Vigor has the carriage of this, I put the proposal to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Before we get too excited about changing the clause yet again, might I remind the Committee about the difficulties that would flow if the clause were recast in the way that Senator Durack is now proposing. That would take us back to the central difficulty that the Government saw and expressed with the original version of Senator Vigor's amendment; that is, that it would put at risk the full useful effect of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill in its operation in relation to those areas where there are some existing legal rights in areas covered by the Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: If we were to draft it in that way we would have standing alongside each other the existing protection, for what it is worth-and I gave as an example the judges' rules in relation to criminal suspects, which are recognised as a matter of common law-and the enhanced protections in the Bill of Rights itself. We would confront the courts and everybody else with the problem of saying which set of rights were, in fact, to be regarded as the governing ones. On normal principles of interpretation we would say that the common law rules were overridden by the statutory formulation of them, especially in that the statutory formulation is, on the example we are using, more far reaching. But if we had a clause expressed in the way Senator Durack has just suggested and that Senator Vigor originally drafted we would have a situation where those normal principles of interpretation would not apply, and we would have sitting there alongside each other the new rights in the Bill of Rights, the new far reaching protection, and the diminished original rights with its, of course, corresponding diminished duties and obligations as far as police officers and so on are concerned. It would create a situation where the diminished right would have at least as much status as the enhanced right under the Bill of Rights. It is an interpretation problem with significant substantive effect that would be created if we went down that particular track. That is the reason. It is not because of any problem in principle about the greater or lesser recognition of other rights, but for that reason that I suggested earlier on-that there were difficulties about the original framing. Those arguments are equally applicable here.

I will conclude while I am on my feet by responding, not again with as much flourish as Senator Sir John Carrick, to one of the points he made. I fully accept his sincerity in arguing, and indeed the force of his argument, that in many ways a crucial guarantor of liberty is the prevailing set of values that operate in a society. I fully accept, and I have accepted it every time I have been on my feet on this topic over the last 10 or 15 years, that rights are better protected in societies with liberal democratic values of the kind that we have in Australia than they are in countries without those traditions, without those values. I draw to Senator Sir John Carrick's attention that very useful distinction between necessary and sufficient conditions when it comes to the argument about Bills of Rights having no effect in totalitarian societies and the suggestions that are made accordingly that a Bill of Rights will have no effect in ours. I fully accept that the existence of a Bill of Rights, statutory or constitutional, is not a sufficient condition for the protection of liberty; that is to say, it is not in itself a sufficient guarantor that liberty will in fact be respected and protected. We need something more than that; we do need a liberal dosage of those values of the kind that Senator Sir John Carrick was talking about. We have to have a Bill of Rights operating in a society where there is a basic substratum of respect for those crucial values.

What I would argue and argue very strongly, but not at great length because it is a familiar argument, is that with all the best will in the world to simply rely on those values, to rely on the self-restraint of legislatures, of bureaucrats, of police officers and all the other people who exercise authority in our society, is not enough. It is not a sufficient condition. It is necessary that we add something more, and that something more is piecemeal legislation such as the sex and racial discrimination legislation but also specifically the kind of over-arching guarantees that we are talking about here with the Bill of Rights. It is that which, to offer one little flourish of my own, was the yeast in the United States, that really turned that slowly evolving public opinion that was beginning to recognise in the early 1950s the enormity of the evil that had been done to the black population of the United States. It was the existence of the Bill of Rights, the equal protection clause, the litigation avenues available under it, that enabled blacks to get ahead of that public opinion and to anticipate it by perhaps two decades, and to get the Supreme Court applying these rules, these prescriptions, in a way that was enormously useful. More than that, it was absolutely crucial to the recognition and protection of that group of people's rights.

In so many other ways that one could refer to Bills of Rights around the world have played that useful role. I am not saying that without a Bill of Rights liberty would be a desert, a non-existent thing; what I am saying is that at the margin Bills of Rights can be very useful indeed, and it is at the margin essentially that this debate is occurring. I say no more. I think it is important that we conclude this debate, time getting on as it is. We recognise the utility of Article 2 in its present form, perhaps a slightly enhanced utility with the extra words that Senator Vigor has proposed. We recognise that this is what the clause is about. I suggest that the Committee should enact it, pass it, and get on to the discussion of what is by universal agreement around the chamber a more substantial issue yet to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to do that, but Senator Evans has just given us one example of what occurred with the Bill of Rights in the United States. He ought to know that it was because certain people were appointed to the Supreme Court of the United States that that occurred. I will give him some other examples of what occurred. Senator Evans is saying that Bills of Rights are the be all and end all of what ought to be done in this-give it to the courts. I remind the honourable senator of what has occurred in respect of the United States Bill of Rights. The rights appear as amendments to the United States Constitution. Let us look at the Tenth Amendment, which deals with rights held by the States and the people. Those rights were included primarily to calm the apprehensions of States rights advocates. In fact, they were later cited frequently by opponents of racial desegregation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fourteenth Amendment originally was enacted to protect the freed man from the abrogation of his rights. That became a virtual nullity as the protection of the rights of negro citizens. Under Article 1 of section 10, the proscription of State violation of the obligation of contracts was interpreted to include everything from private contracts to State-granted charters of incorporations to private companies. The second section of the Eighteenth Amendment was designed to protect dry States against the violation of their laws. That has become, by interpretation, something not intended at all. The Supreme Court of the United States has held that the amendment permits States to levy taxes on the importation of liquor from other States; a kind of tax that until that time was clearly unconstitutional.

Under the establishment clause of the American Constitution a State may not proscribe from its school curriculum the teaching of Darwin's theory of evolution because of `its supposed conflict with the biblical account, literally read'. There is also the example to which I referred previously. Still further is the decision of the Supreme Court upholding the Hatch Act, which forbids most Federal employees from engaging in active political party affairs. They are all interpretations of broadly based so-called human rights provisions in the United States of America. Take the First Amendment relating to the freedom of speech. That has been used in the United States by the purveyors of hard-core pornography to attempt to strike down the laws in that country relating to censorship and obscenity. That is what we will be opening up with this Bill of Rights. For Senator Evans to accuse us, as it were, of being against human rights is pathetic. I believe that if human rights need protection, we as members of Parliament, particularly as members of this Senate which has prided itself over the years as being the protector of individual rights, ought to be the ones who do so by statute law, not by this broad approach of setting into a Bill of Rights broad fundamental laws to be interpreted by a non-elected Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which is a propaganda body as well. I use that not in the pejorative sense, but it will be a propaganda body which is non-elected, as are the courts. If we make mistakes we have to suffer those mistakes and cop it. If we make mistakes the people can vote us out of office, or vote individual senators or members out of office. If the courts make decisions which have far reaching effects on society and on individuals in society and if those people are frustrated by those decisions, they do not have any recourse against those who have made those decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can change the law.
—Senator Evans said that we can change the law. Yes, we can change the law.
—We have the last word.

—We have the last word. Listen to what he is saying. Last night we heard Senator Janine Haines ask 10 or 12 questions of the Minister. She asked whether the Minister would ensure that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, as its first job after this Bill goes through, went to Queensland and looked at the Queensland electoral laws. She also asked the Minister to ensure that a report came to the Parliament on that question. What do honourable senators think will happen about all of this? Will the Parliament be able to withstand the sorts of pressure that will be applied? Parliament may be able to, but certainly the Government will not. What will happen? The Government will make political appointments to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, give that body an agenda and it will give its recommendations to Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what we have told the courts in respect of the question I mentioned before, as just one of the examples. Under the Acts Interpretation Act the Government, in its explanatory memorandum, has put the courts in a straitjacket. The Government is not requiring the courts to do what Senator Sir John Carrick said ought to be done and what the Minister said earlier ought to be done; that is, there are special duties and responsibilities for the respect of the rights or reputations of others. The Minister has discarded that; it is not in the Bill for the courts to consider. In respect of freedom of expression the Government has deliberately left out the words contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the words `protection of morals'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not deliberately left them out. The explanatory memorandum directs the courts to go to the Covenant.
—No.
—Rubbish! It is an appendix to the statute.
—Clause 3 (2) states that it is only insofar as it is a limitation of the right, not an extension of the right.
—It is not an extension of the right.

—It is an extension of the right. For example, let us look at freedom of expression as it relates to a purveyor of pornography. We on the Joint Select Committee on Video Material have had evidence that much of this stuff is generated by the Mafia. An organised criminal group could use the freedom of expression provision in the Bill of Rights to attack the laws in this country which, inadequate as they are, give some protection to the rights of the citizens on the basis of this question of protection of respect for the rights and reputations of others and the protection of morals. Why do we do that in respect of children? The Government has deliberately left out the word `morals' and the Minister will have to explain why.
—It is not deliberately left out.
—Put it back in.
—All right, we will put it back. No problems.
—Will the Minister put those words in clause 3?
—Not in the clause. I will explain why in a minute.
—Of course the Minister will not put them in there. I do not think Senator Vigor has fallen for it, because I believe that he will support the amendment and he is sticking to his guns.

SPEECH.PARA: I admire him for that. I am not going to fall for what Senator Gareth Evans has just said because it indicates clearly what the Government has done; that is, it has ignored all of the provisions in the articles in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and changed the derogation power so that it relates only to what is a reasonable limitation prescribed by law as can be demonstrated justified in a free and democratic society. Is not the United States a free and democratic society? Look what has happened there with its obscenity laws.

I believe that we have come to a crossroad. The clause that has been recognised is an insubstantial clause but it has permitted a debate which has gone to the essence of the problem. For my part I believe we, as members of parliament, do have the responsibility of ensuring that the rights of individuals if they are not adequately catered for by common law or in other ways are properly protected by specific statute law. This is not a specific statute law; it is a law which details broadly based rights and it passes over to non-elected bodies the task of interpreting those particular laws in accordance with the straitjacket guidelines that have been put to them by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said about the American Bill of Rights. Senator Sir John Carrick has said that he has actually been to the United States of America, he has been amongst the blacks, he has lived among them as if they were some strange group of people and has observed them. Senator Harradine has studied the Bill of Rights. But I do not think either one of these fine gentlemen has actually appreciated the Bill of Rights for what it is. The Bill of Rights has allowed America to change with the times. It was established well over 200 years ago. The Americans could never have foreseen all the changes which would happen in that country over that period and so it was left open to interpretation; it had to be broad. One cannot go running to parliament every time something changes. It has to be open to interpretation, and that is what the courts did-they interpreted it, and they interpreted it as the situation changed.
—Depending on the appointments to the Supreme Court.

—Depending on the appointments to the Supreme Court, but America does not have long-running governments and it works out that the Supreme Court gets a pretty balanced set of judges. It is incredible in the United States that even those who start out as avid right wingers when they are promoted often see the light and become more progressive. Perhaps the same thing could happen here. Even retired Liberal politicians might be appointed to some High Court office and see the light and become progressive in their old age. One would hope that that might happen.

SPEECH.PARA: In the United States not too long ago the Governor of Georgia, Lester Maddox, was proud to hand out axe handles to people and say: `Go beat up the blacks. I will turn a blind eye. Go ahead and beat up the blacks'. He owned a restaurant and did not want integration in his restaurant. We tend to view the United States from this end as a nation of excesses. I suppose it is, but it is not the only place in the world where injustice exists; it can exist here. It is becoming more and more prevalent in Australia. We have a situation in Tasmania, which is not unlike the Georgia of the 1960s, where people who are not in favour with the Government, as the blacks were not in Georgia, where they were not even allowed to vote, can be assaulted in front of police while the police stand by and do nothing. This is exactly what happened at Farmhouse Creek, where the environmentalists were breaking no law and yet they were deprived of their civil rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Sanders, would you come back to Article 2, please.

—Much has been said here about civil rights and about the American Bill of Rights. I am pointing out that we do need the same type of protection as the Bill of Rights has been giving. We have had the Bill of Rights denigrated in this chamber. I am defending the Bill of Rights and showing that it is needed in this country to protect the rights of citizens because of the excesses now being shown by State governments. We will get into this matter later and discuss why it should extend to State governments.
—We will get into it in about July at the present rate.

—Perhaps by July, as Senator Gareth Evans says, but we do need it; we need it very soon. I would like to point out that unless people here really have studied the American Bill of Rights and lived with it they should not comment adversely upon it, because I believe it has helped to solve many of the social problems which have plagued that country and could do a great deal for this country as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to be vexatious, but we have just had a statement from Senator Sanders that there were great virtues lying in the Bill of Rights and that they protected the people of the United States of America. I ask honourable senators and Senator Sanders in particular whether they have heard of the Yellow Dog contract. Does Senator Sanders know what a milestone that was? It was a contract upheld by the courts under the Bill of Rights and a contract that was only rejected in the end when along came President Roosevelt and changed the Supreme Court. As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) would know, that contract was one of the ugliest denials of rights. It was a contract which said: `In consideration of you giving me a job I will guarantee that I will not get into any kind of organisation at all'.
—It was the spirit of the age that created that constraint in the first place.

—Senator Gareth Evans will know the Sacco Vanzetti case. It was an absolute milestone in the lack of freedom for the American people. I put this to the honourable senator because the Bill of Rights did not make these decisions at all. The matter lay fundamentally in the quality of the hearts and minds of the people who were appointed to the Supreme Court. It is important to know that the only reason that the Yellow Dog contract went was not because someone challenged it under the Bill of Rights. The Bill of Rights allowed it. It was because Mr Roosevelt conceived the idea that he could pass a law to retire judges at a particular age and, therefore, put in a completely new set of judges who interpreted the Bill of Rights as saying that the yellow dog contract was a foul thing and ought to go. How can anyone get up in this place, knowing American history and knowing the evil that surrounded the Sacco Vanzetti situation over the years in America, and say that these things could not happen under a Bill of Rights? They happened because there was not a judiciary that was sensitive to the rights and freedoms of the people. They happened because a judiciary did not regard itself as a custodian of rights. It was only after the Supreme Court was changed with vigour and violence by President Roosevelt that so many of the absolute tyrannies that lay around America were abolished. So let us not have any lectures on the fundamental basis of the Bill of Rights. What it simply means is that, just as in Russia--
—The courts cannot operate unless they have rights established.

—Yes, but let me remind the Committee that there is a Bill of Rights in Russia. The interpretation of the Bill of Rights by the Kremlin leads to an entirely different situation. The Bill of Rights of itself does not have too many blemishes. It is the interpretation of it by the executive, by the judiciary, that brings about the problem. I never thought that I would find--
—It is chaotic if you do not have any statutes upon which the court can rule.

—I am interested in the interjection because I acknowledge that Senator Georges is one who in his own light has fought for rights. I may not agree with him, but I respect the fact that he has fought for freedoms and rights. Indeed, the fact is that in this country we have not had to resort either to referendum or to statute to protect the valuable rights we have.
—We do not have all those rights; that is the whole point.

—Senator Sanders has shown his deficiencies to the world by that remarkably simplistic attempt to see all virtue in a written Bill of Rights. I acknowledge that when the American Bill of Rights was written-I think it was in 1791 that the clauses were approved-it was a valuable instrument for that day. I acknowledge that over the years the interpretations by the courts have created, as is the case with our own Constitution, an entirely different meaning to the Bill of Rights than it was ever meant to have.
—They had a basic document upon which to work.

—What I say to the Committee and to Senator Georges is that his freedoms and rights-the very right he is asserting daily, the right to challenge the law of the day, the right to be different, the right to take up causes-are enshrined now. We do not need a Bill of Rights to do what Senator Georges has done.
—It is easier to do it with a Bill of Rights.

—One does not need it at all. The fact that he can do it is vital. I simply rose to say that one should not cite simplistic cases. One should refer to American history and ask about the Hoover regime and the Yellow Dog contract. One should ask about Sacco Vanzetti. One should ask about all of these kinds of things and remember, therefore, that it was not the protection of a Bill of Rights, it was the protection of a reformed Supreme Court that gave the ultimate freedoms to the people in America.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to say anything, but I must refute this rather petty argument. Senator Sir John Carrick picked out several examples. Certainly, no one has ever said that the Bill of Rights has ever covered all instances and that no injustices were ever created in the United States under the jurisdiction of the Bill of Rights. What we are seeing here is a case of privilege. Senator Sir John Carrick does not need a Bill of Rights. He is protected in this country by the Establishment, by the web of protection that surrounds the privileged in this country. This Bill of Rights is for people whom he does not represent and who would not vote for him-people who have no money and no status in the community. Those are the people a Bill of Rights defends and has defended.

SPEECH.PARA: He talked about simplistic cases. If he wants to name yellow dog cases and others, I am sure we can go through them one by one and show that the advantages of the Bill of Rights far outweigh any abuses that have happened in the United States and which were ultimately sorted out, as even he must admit. Once again, I must say that in my mind the Bill of Rights allowed the United States to reach its pinnacle of democratic development. It is now going downhill simply because of the right wing white-anting of those freedoms by people such as Senator Sir John Carrick. I deplore it in the United States and I would deplore it in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the amendment Senator Vigor first moved on behalf of the Australian Democrats gave very real expression to concerns which not only are held by the Democrats but also very widely in the community. They are concerns which are shared entirely by the Opposition. However, the problem with the wording of the first form of Senator Vigor's amendment was that it referred to a `right existing apart from this Bill of Rights'. It would be very difficult for anybody to ascertain the meaning of that without further explanation. When he spoke to it, of course, he did explain it, but we were still left with the problem as to how it would be interpreted, as it undoubtedly would be, by the courts in due course. When this was pointed out to Senator Vigor he sought to amend the existing provision in article 2 to read:

SPEECH.PARA: A right or freedom existing under, or recognised by, any other law, convention or custom shall not be taken to have been diminished or derogated from by reason only that the right or freedom is not set out in this Bill of Rights.

The point is that the purpose of the Government in bringing in article 2 is quite different from the purpose Senator Vigor had in proposing his original amendment. He desired, quite rightly, to preserve a whole range of rights which people enjoy-apart from those contained in this Bill of Rights-under other laws, be they laws of this Parliament, judgments of the courts or, indeed, as he has expanded it, with the consent of the Government to cover conventions and customs. It is a very broad, wide concept which goes beyond the narrow definition of legal rights to which this Bill is directed. It is directed only to limiting rights or guaranteeing rights that are set out in this Bill. It virtually ignores, apart from this article, all the other rights that may be contained not only in legislation that has been passed already, but also in legislation which may be passed in the future.
Consideration interrupted.
